Features Include - Audience Cards,Star Ratings Chart,Contracts, Publicity and Hit or Flop.
The first player to make £50,000 has proven to be successful and is the winner of the game.

Stars include - Dickie Valentine, James Arness, Tommy Trinder, Benny Hill, Lucille Ball, Petula Clark and many more.
categories: Economic, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Negotiation

name: Flower Power
description:
The players put plastic discs onto their flower cards. They throw the dice to obtain the plastic discs but they must also be careful about how they combine them. Only if the right discs are put on top of each other will the correct flower colour emerge.

Contents:
• 4 wooden flower cards (180 x 140 x 4 mm)
• 1 dice with colours and symbols
• 24 round plastic discs
• 1 coloured Beleduc Box

name: ZOMBIES!  You Won't Survive The Night.
description:
Well, it's finally happened. It might have been a plague, some sort of crazy military experiment, or just a freak mutation of some virus; but it doesn't matter, the dead are walking and they are hungry!

ZOMBIES! You Won't Survive The Night is a Zombie-themed card game where you and your friends make up a party of survivors who are doing their best to simply survive. The only problem... They won't! You cannot survive this night! Everyone WILL DIE!!!

While you and your friends are trying to make it, you will go into houses and businesses looking for food and weapons. On occasion, you might just find a Zombie... Of course, dealing with the Zombies in a large group (Up to 10 players) might seem easy at first but eventually you lose people... and when you do, they become Zombies too!

Play doesn't end when you die, your priorities simply change. Once you die and become a Zombie, your goal is simple: Kill all the living and eat their brains!

Will you be the last to survive? Will you be the last Zombie standing? Each play-through will be different in this game of tactics and chance.

name: Augen Auf!
description:
Contents
16 picture cards
16 question cards

Promotional game published by a children's sweets company

The game is a simple quiz game with question cards and picture cards. When a question is read out, the child who has to answer it must sort through the pictures and find an example of the subject in the question.

name: Der kleine Eisbär Bist du mein Freund?
description: Lars, Robby, Caruso, Nena und Nanuk are very good friends and have sworn eternal friendship. Each player has a face-down stack of cards and in his turn can take up to three cards and try to find one to add to the last card placed. He can place a card when the big friend is the same as the small one in the corners of the last card placed. If no card fits, he puts all back into his stack and tries to remember which friends where on those cards. The first player to place all his cards wins the game.

name: Hallo Maus!
description: The Mouse shows how things work or what one needs to do some things, players try to find the necessary things. Each player draws a mouse card face down, they are turned up simultaneously. All players try to find the corresponding thing cards, but must look forst for those that belong to other players’ mouse cards. When all cards of the round are found, players get the mouse cards fitting to the thing card(s) they collected from the other players. Who has the most mouse cards at the end wins the game.

name: Berliner Sammelsurium Das Spiel
description:
Humorous quiz game about Berlin.
Goal of the game is to reach Lehrter station first. You can advance through luck of the dice, correct answers, real wealth, misleading other players and ignorance of the other players.
Players roll the dice and if arrow is rolled he moves up the ladder. If "K", "S" or "W" is rolled player takes a creative, estimate or knowledge card from the deck and asks a question. There is a short game and a team option.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Witch: Oraakkelin kutsu
description:
Game themed on Disney Italia's W.I.T.C.H. comic.
Each player has 5 pawns, and they race to get all the pawns to the center of the board while evading "banscáil"-pawn.

Contents:
Board
20 pawns (in 4 different colours)
Banscáil-pawn with base
2 dice
Rules
categories: Children's Game, Comic Book / Strip, Dice, Fantasy

name: 1,2 oder 3 das Spiel
description:
Objective: collect as many winning chips as possible

close to the rules of the popular TV-show you try to mislead your opponents placing your meeple as short as possible before the jingle is sounding onto 'true area'
the magic pen shows the correct answer (out of 3) and you should get a chip if you were right
content:
- board
- magic pen
- 198 x 2 question & answer cards
- 90 chips
- 9 meeples
- rules
battery is needed (for magic pen working)
depending on edition no. of cards may vary
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Trivia

name: Diddls Käsekuchenland-Spiel
description:
Objective: Collect as many cheese cake pieces as possible by moving around the board
- moving/acting by turn -
each player has to collect cheese cake pieces for Diddle. You can achieve this if you have to draw a question card => give the right answer or
if you draw an action card => perform required action properly
If all players are back in Diddls' cave the one who gained most of the pieces wins
categories: Action / Dexterity, Card Game, Children's Game, Dice, Trivia

name: Identity  Spiel der Persönlichkeiten
description:
Objective:
be the first to make correct guesses who has taking over someone's identity (out of players circle)

Each player has to adopt an identity out of participating teammates. Answers should be given out of the perspective of 'transferred' identity. Players must making guesses who is playing whose identity.
- acting by turn -
1 draw a card
2 let anyone reply to asked question
3 make a guess which identity is simulated by this player
4 if someone has bet on each teammate game ends
5 each straight tip - given or received - will count
categories: Card Game, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game
mechanics: Open Drafting, Role Playing, Simulation, Storytelling

name: Pukemaster
description:
From the website:
PUKEMASTER gets every party started, and is a brilliant drinking game for both single and team players. During the game you will face several challenges, which you help to develop. You’re the one who sets the limit!

If you’re not in a festive mood after playing PUKEMASTER, you haven’t played it right!

The board game has a very cheeky and smooth design. You can just wipe of the game board, if you should spill.The game board is magnetic, hence you can play the game everywhere – on the bus, at the festival, at the beach, or in the park.

The game board measures 16x16x4 cm. That’s why it is so easy to carry with you. When the magnetic game board is folded out, it measures only 30×30 cm. Perfect for the bar desk, at your favorite bar!

name: Europa-Spiel
description:
Objective: trivia-game; move your stones (meeples) up to 'high scoring' positions
- moving by turn -
roll the die, select and move one of your stones, draw cards (if your stone enters scoring positions), reply on questions (if your stone crosses a question mark)
if you give an incorrect answer you have to move your stone into 'left' area, otherwise right (=better) area
you may 'kick' opponent's stones
if a stone reaches 'top level' all stones on lowest level are eliminated
game ends, if all remaining stones are placed on scoring positions

name: Sternenschweif     Der Goldene Schlüssel
description:
Objective: be the first solving 5 quests and become the "Guardian of the Golden Key"
One of a series of Kosmos games based on the My Secret Unicorn books by Linda Chapman.
In Germany, the series goes by the name, "Sternenschweif" (Star Tail) and the books are also published by Kosmos.
- acting by turn -
7 (out of 48) cards are given to each player
try to collect matching symbols to solve a quest (totally 5)
if you are successful discard the matching ones and fill up your hand
some special cards - like Joker - simplify tasks
due to the fact that last round must be completed a tie is possible

name: xPirate
description:
Come set sail with xPirate - the world's first-ever game that combines a traditional game board with the iPhone, iPod Touch or iPad! The iPad/iPhone/iPod acts as a "Game Master", controlling elements of what happens to the pirates as they search for buried treasure.

Object of the Game

Travel across dangerous waters on the hunt for 4 hidden treasures before sailing back home for victory!

Treasures - include gold, jewels, supplies & secret treasures.
Islands - while searching for treasure, you can trade on the island markets - buying and selling what you need to survive your journey.
Beware - you'll encouter raging typhoons, dangerous krakens, deadly ship attacks, skeleton armies and even attacks from your fellow players!

name: Pjovert
description:
PJOVERT - a partygame below the belt!

What are you going to do, when the evening needs an extra twist? Pull out your Pjovert!

Pjovert, drawn and invented by Morten Ingemann, Ruth Lorentzen, Svend Schat-Holm and Susanne Ingemann Schat-Holm, is a new funny game with questions about everything that happens below the belt.

Even though the game is naughty in a funny way, you will not be embarresed, when you play Pjovert - you will get lots of laughs and new knowledge. There are 6 categories, with 100 questions or tasks about life downunder.

Quick to start: Roll the two dice, move your pjovert around on the board, and answer a question or do a task. In that way you can win rings. Whoever gets 6 different coloured rings around his pjovert wins the game!

A game takes 30-60 minutes, and can be played by two to six players.

name: KenTron
description:
KenTron or the bees chess. This game opposes two swarms of bees that fight for a 91-hexagon beehive. The player's pieces and their movements are: a queen (one hex in any direction), drones (jump over adjacent hexes), adult workers (any number of hexes in any direction, no jumps allowed), young workers (one hex forward). If a young worker reaches one of the 5
opponent’s pollen hexes she is promoted to an adult worker. If a bee finds an opponent’s bee in one of the hexes where she could arrive, she can kill her. When a queen is threatened by an opponent’s bee and she cannot escape to a safe hex nor she cannot protect herself with another bee, the player loses the game.

Our word "centre" is a word that we have inherited from Ancient Greek. The greeks called kentron the centre of a circumference, because kentron was the compass needle. But the primitive meaning of kentron was the insect sting. Kentron also meant "the spike of the spear", and this is the name that this chess-like game recieves.

name: Das elektrische Rätselraten
description: East German (DDR) quiz game, using the electrical format. Players get to answer a question by sticking the contact into the relative answer on the question and answer sheet. If they are correct, a light lights up. Winner is the one who answers the most questions correctly.
publishers: Combina, Gordon, Piko, Stockinger & Morsack, VEM

name: Activity 1996
description: Expansion for the Activity with 110 new cards about what happens in 1996.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Party Game

name: Take Over
description:
In business, a take over is the purchase of one company by another (the acquirer or bidder), usually the first competitor.
Each player represents a major European businessman at the head of an industrial empire.
Each industrial group will try to grow placing factories on the map of the European nations and by selling its products on markets. The players will try to win the position of economic dominance in Europe buying companies of the opponents (Take Over).
The winner will be the owner of three different markets.

name: Cranium: Glee Edition
description:
Publisher Blurb:

Outrageous Gleek fun for everyone!
Join the Glee club and hum, dance, act and mimic to become the ultimate Gleek! Celebrate everything Glee with friends and family as you. . .
SKETCH works of art like Puck;
PERFORM like a star and act like Brittany Pierce;
PLAY with words - give the definition of a Patriotic Wedgie; and
SOLVE multiple choice questions like:
What does Sue think Will’s breath smells like?
• Stupidity
• Failure
• Greatness
• Mediocrity
Enjoy this playful game that delivers Glee fun and laughter, and stretches the imagination every time!
Game includes: 16 Fun activities, 600 Glee-themed cards, 4 “Loser” movers, game board, 1 tub of “Cranium Clay”, Sand timer, 1 die, pad and pencil.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Puzzle, Trivia, Word Game
mechanics: Acting, Line Drawing, Paper-and-Pencil, Roll / Spin and Move, Singing, Team-Based Game

name: Caption It!
description:
Party game where guests can use their wits (if they have any!!).

There are 12 different cartoons and the object of the game is to compose a humourous or witty caption for each picture.

The host can decide the funniest for each of the 12 cartoons and the player (or team) who get the most 'accepts', wins.

name: Tic-Tac Bingo Game
description:
Tic Tac Bingo Game: Preschoolers can either play Tic Tac Toe or Bingo. For Bingo, one player drops both the color and character dice through the dice tower. All players simultaneously try to match the correct color and character on their player card by placing a chip on the correct space. The first player to get Bingo, wins. For Tic Tac Toe, one player drops the character die through the dice tower and only that player tries to match the character on their player card by placing a chip on the correct space. The next player takes a turn. The first player to get Tic Tac Toe, wins.

Contents:

4 Double-Sided Game Boards
56 Game Chips (4 Different Colors)
2 Dice
1 Dice Tower
categories: Abstract Strategy, Children's Game, Dice, Real-time
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Pattern Recognition, Set Collection, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Trav-L-Bingo
description:
A game to make a long car journey a little easier.

Each player (hopefully not including the driver!) is given a 5 x 5 bingo card. The cards feature various things you might see out of the windows during the trip. If you see something, announce it to the other players (who can check that you aren't cheating), and then mark the item on your card.

A long game could be all the 25 items on your card. But a shorter game should be that the winner is the first player to complete a line of items.

Made by Gulf, the oil and petrol supplier, and mailed out in an envelope so no box needed. As the bingo cards need to be cut up into single cards, I would guess this is a pretty rare item to find in its complete, original shape.

name: Junior Millionen Quiz
description:
Objective:
be the first to climb up 20 spaces reaching the top (golden area) giving correct answers on multiple-choice questions (1 out of 4)
- acting by turn -
determine the difficulty level first (easy, moderate, difficult)
each player is asked a question:
if answer is right ==> step forewards; wrong ==> step backwards

3.300 questions (standard edition) out of:
> heaven & earth
> animals & nature
> technique
> sports & games
> fairy tales & stories
> wild mixture

name: Jig-Words
description:
A word game. The pieces have both letters and black squares on them. The objective is to use all your tiles by making a correct Crossword. The player wins if he has used his last tile.

It can be played as a puzzle or it can be played competitively.

The box claims:
A Boon to the Sick
Days of Amusement
Entirely New and Novel
A 'Service' Favourite
186 tiles

The 'Service' reference probably means the game was published within the years 1939 to 1945 (World War II).
publishers: G. N. Raymond, Universal Publications Ltd

name: Paper Trails: Road Trip!
description:
50 tear-off sheets in each Paper Trails pad make this an ideal travel game. Each game combines the luck of the dice and strategy in the attempt to reach the destination before your opponent. Be the first to the finish line in a race across America in the ROAD TRIP! Edition. Each Paper Trails includes a 50-sheet Game Pad, a Pencil and Die.

Each player starts from a starting position. Players roll dice to see how far they move. A bad roll results in damage. If a player receives too much damage is out of the game. Once players reach a checkpoint, they must roll dice each turn until their total equals/exceeds that checkpoint's number. The first player to clear all four checkpoints and reach the finish wins the game.

name: Batman Swoops Down
description:
"A Fast,Thrilling,Action Packed Game."

Robin the Boy Wonder has been captured by Batman's enemies. It is impossible for him to escape without assistance. Only Batman can set Robin free and to do so, he must overpower three of his villains,who are on guard in adjoining positions.

Each player has a flipper,a Batman and 4 counters. Batman is placed on the flipper and is flipped with a finger towards the board centre - Thus swooping down on the target. If he lands on one of the 8 enemy spaces, the player's coloured counter is placed there. Land in the centre and you gain an extra turn.

The player who first gets 3 counters in adjoining spaces has freed Robin and wins the game.

Contents
1 Game Surface.
4 Flipper's.
4 Playing Pieces.
24 Counter's.
Rules are printed on inner box lid.

name: Fur & Feathers
description:
Fur & Feathers is a fun, fact-filled, educational game about animals and how our everyday choices affect their lives. The object of the game is to be the first player to save one of each of the five animals (dog, cat, pig, cow and chicken). Players can do so by correctly answering interesting animal fact questions, visiting the Cafe’and ordering from a kid friendly menu (which offers healthy alternative items like soup & salad, pasta, etc.), visiting the Animal Shelter and adopting a pet or by the luck of the spinner at the Farm.

Fur & Feathers game features various spaces that allow players to move ahead, forward, visit one of the three animal areas and other positive experiences. It was designed with children in mind and has no negative consequences, the players always have a fun experience during game play.

There are plenty of fun ways to win the game but strategy and a little luck can help too!

name: Quick-Quiz: Weite Welt
description:
"World Wide" in English
108 game cards with 500 questions and 500 answers.
The question is asked and the quickest player with correct answer gets a point. Who collect 25 points first wins the game.

Contents:

108 playing cards,
notepad and pencil

name: Quick-Quiz: Natur
description:
"Nature" in English
108 game cards with 500 questions and 500 answers.
The question is asked and the quickest player with correct answer gets a point. Who collect 25 points first wins the game.

Contents:

108 playing cards,
notepad and pencil

name: IQ Trainer
description:
Objective: be the first reaching top of the board/ranking list (= genius)
- acting by turn -
1 each player rolls the die to determine the section (question cards) '6' = free of choice;
2 find the answer within a certain time - usually a minute
3 if you were right - 1 step up ==> direction 'genius'; wrong - 1 step down ==> direction 'mutt'
player may use certain materials (paper, pencil...), and spend chips (6 at the start) to extend required time

remark: same approach was used for 'Das IQ Spiel für Kinder'

name: Quick-Quiz: Allgemeinwissen
description:
"General knowledge" in English
108 game cards with 500 questions and 500 answers.
The question is asked and the quickest player with correct answer gets a point. Who collect 25 points first wins the game.

Contents:

108 playing cards,
notepad and pencil

name: Round Up
description:
Each player has a Marker and a Ranch. Place the steer discs on the board as per instructions. Spin the arrow to move. When landing on a square bearing your own brand - Take 1 steer from the pool and place it in your corral. Players can lose steers by landing on certain squares.
A Stampede can be an unpleasant place to land. It means you must spin for every steer in your corral - You must spin a 6 to keep them!

The objective is to be the first player to round up 6 steers and get them safely corralled.

Contents
1 Game Board.
1 Spinner.
4 Playing Pieces.
24 Steer Discs.
Rules Are Printed on Inner Box Base.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Wills's Woodbine Cricket Game
description:
Promotional game by the Wills Woodbine cigarettes manufacturer.

The game is a rectangular metal board, with a lever on the top and two windows, one for when you are out, the other for how many runs you scored with that ball. There is a sliding 'door' that is moved over the wheel that is not relevant at the time.

You start with the runs indicator window being open. Press the lever and the wheel will spin around. The number showing when it stops is how many runs you scored with that delivery. But if the result is How's That, then you are out, and the runs scored wheel is blocked off and you again press the lever to see how you were out.

The player that scores the most runs after all their wickets have fallen, wins.

name: Pokemon Quick Capture!
description:
Race to catch the Pokemon!

From the box: "Ready, Set, Go!" It's an all-out race to catch Pokemon! Every player plays on ever turn in this Pokemon capturing frenzy. But watch out! It takes quick reflexes and fast thinking to snag the Pokemon you need to win! Features 36 all-new Pokemon from the Black and White televesion series!"

The game uses pattern-matching skills to claim cards after capturing pokemon on the board.

Players turn over 3 cards each round. Each card lists 2 pieces of data which can be used to match one of three pieces of data listed on the game board for each Pokemon. You only need to match one thing to be able to capture the Pokemon. After you've played all three cards, you then check to see if you match any of the pattern cards set by the side of the board, ranging from 2 to 5 points. If you can claim a pattern, you keep that card and get the points. Once all 8 pattern cards are claimed, the game is over. It's all explained on one small two-sided rules sheet.

name: Ivanhoe
description:
Objective: be the very last of the round keeping Ivanhoe in your hands
'A Parlor game based on the story of Sir Walter Scott'
- acting by turn -
total 31 cards (15 duplicates + Ivanhoe)
1 entire pack is dealt - if someone holds a pair it's laid aside
2 player who holds Ivanhoe informs the others
3 during a turn you must draw a card - if you 'pair' ==> the 2 cards must lay down
4 player who holds Ivanhoe has the advantage drawing 2 cards
(from one or another or the same person)
5 when a player obtains Ivanhoe card must be shown to others
and then put back in his/her hand
6 after all cards have been formed into pairs player holding Ivanhoe wins
remarks:
Cards are: Ivanhoe (1), Lokesley (Robin Hood), De Bracy, Wamba the Jester, Princess Rowena, Rebecca, Sir Brian de Bois Guilbert, Isaac of York, Prior Aymer, King Richard, Friar Tuck, Prince John, Hubert, Cedric the Saxon, Athelstane, Reginald Front de Boeuf

name: Vorschul-Wissensquiz
description:
Objective: help children solving as many questions as possible - improve their knowledge
- acting by turn; game must be assisted by adults/older children -
roll the (coloured) die and move your meeple
draw 1 of more out of 500 questions with 6 (coloured) areas:
- colours
- shapes
- antagonisms
- all in a tumble
- be part of?
- won't fit?
question samples: colour of your heart? stuff dogs like? ...

content:
cards, 6 meeples, 1 d6, 1 coloured die, rules

name: Schloss Immermehr
description:
From the publishers website:

For years on end something mysterious happens every year on a snowy winter night: snow is falling and the snowflakes keep falling thicker and faster and the pile of snow slowly turns into a wonderful castle – Castle Evermore.

The snow piles up higher and higher, gradually covering objects up. Can you recognize the different sizes of the growing castle?

Castle Evermore is a different size on each card. If the castle size on one of your own cards fits between two of your opponent’s cards, you are allowed to pinch his cards.

Whoever has the most cards in a row without any gaps lying in front of him at the end of the game is the winner.

name: DIG: the Card Game – Black Diamond Promo Card
description:
Black Diamond is a promo card for DIG: the Card Game that can be added to the deck for more game play variety. Simply shuffle the card into the starting deck and play. The pertinent rules are included on the card itself.

Card Text:
Always sells for 6 Gold Coins; do not shuffle back into the Mine Deck.

Note: The Black Diamond is a once-per-game find, adding additional excitement and fun every time your Dwarves go digging.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy

name: DIG: the Card Game – Dwarf Thief Promo Card
description:
Dwarf Thief is a promo card for DIG: the Card Game that can be added to the deck for more game play variety. Simply shuffle the card into the starting deck and play. The pertinent rules are included on the card itself.

Card Text:
Always costs 6 Gold Coins. Play in your Play Area. Steal 2 Gold Coins from any 1 Player during each Dig Phase.

Note: The Dwarf Thief does not dig or mine; instead, simply play him face-up in your play area as soon as you hire him. From then on, during each Dig Phase, you may steal 2 Gold Coins from any 1 player. So, for example, if you hire the Dwarf Thief on Day 2, you can feasibly net 10 Gold Coins (2 Gold Coins per day on Days 2-6).
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy

name: Camette
description:
Camette is a pure two-player abstract played on a very small board. Hence it plays very fast, especially since the object is to get any one piece onto an opponent's goal space-- which that player canot occupy himself. As in all games of this family, there are two different types of pieces which mostly move similarly. Pieces can jump over friendly pieces and jump over enemy pieces to capture them. With a board this small, sudden leaps to victory are common.

For those familiar with Camelot (1888):

Camette is a down-sized version of Camelot, even smaller than Cam, with a further reduced board size and number of pieces. Camette was invented by Michael Wortley Nolan in 2002.

Camette is different than Camelot in the following ways:

1. The Camette board has 23 squares. The Camelot board has 160 squares.

2. Each side in Camette has one Knight and three Men. Each side in Camelot has four Knights and ten Men.

3. The object of Camette is to get one piece into the opponent's Castle. The object of Camelot is to get two pieces into the opponent's Castle.

4. Victory in Camette also occurs if one side, even with only one remaining piece, captures all of the opposing pieces. In Camelot, if the side capturing all of the opposing pieces has only one remaining piece, the game is a draw. Victory in Camelot by capture of all of the opposing pieces occurs only if the victorious side has two or more remaining pieces.

5. Stalemate in Camette is impossible. Stalemate in Camelot is possible, and is a victory for the stalemating side if it has two or more pieces.

6. In Camette, if both sides have only one remaining piece, the game continues until one piece captures the other, or one piece enters the opposing Castle. In Camelot, if both sides have only one remaining piece, the game is a draw.

name: Kraterschreck im Mondversteck
description:
Game description from the publisher:

Little green men are a product of the imagination? That's what these spacemen thought until they learned otherwise during a trip to the moon. Once they arrived there, the alien Ansgar had a lot of fun trying to scare the little space travelers.

In Kraterschreck im Mondversteck, you don't know exactly when Ansgar will spring forth from a crater once again – only that he'll definitely do so at some point! The players travel on the game board in a circle with their three spacemen, and depending on the roll of the dice, they move not only their own characters but also Ansgar, who moves invisbly amongst the craters. If Ansgar pops up in a crater close to any spacemen, they'll scatter, leaving the moon to others.

Whoever has the best memory, a little luck with the dice, and the longest lasting spacemen will win!

name: Malmö: spelet om din stad
description:
The first game in a serie of Swedish cities.
"We Are Sailing" says that they with the game wanted to show the changes that the city of Malmö has gone through during the last 10-20 years.

The game is kind of monopoly with trivia questions about the city of Malmo.

name: Junior Elexikon
description:
An electronic dictionary quiz game for younger players.
Players answer the questions with electronic pen what flashes green if the answer is correct.
Who has more correct answers at the end of the game is the winner.

name: The Game of London
description:
A Victorian card game, featuring 55 cards showing the contemporary locations in London. Many of these buildings are no longer around and, if you know London at all, you will notice the fact that still-existing buildings are not hemmed in by modern developments and office blocks as they are now.

The game is played with 64 cards - 55 picture cards, 8 District cards and 1 Key Card. The Key Card contains the numbers of picture cards in each district. It is placed face-up in the middle of the table. The remaining 63 cards are all shuffled and dealt to the players in rotation until the pack is exhausted.

The game is commenced by the player to the left of the dealer asking any other player for a card to complete a district of which he holds at least one card in his hand. If a player asked has such a card in his hand, he is bound to surrender it, and the first player then asks for another and so on until refused, when the right of asking is transferred to the player who refused him. The latter, in like manner, then asks for a card to complete a district in his hand, and so the game proceeds until all the districts are completed. Each district, when completed, is to be laid on the table (face downwards) by the player, and the game is won by that player who, at the conclusion, holds the most districts. A player may, at any time, refer to the Key Card in the centre of the table.

The game is undated, but one of the picture cards refers to "the late Sir Gilbert Scott", the most famous Victorian architect. He died in 1878 so the game was probably new around 1880.

name: Jugger: An Indian Game
description:
Early 20th century card game published by a Missionary Society, with the intention of making people aware of their work in the sub-continent. The game is fundamentally about India although Ceylon (now Sri Lanka) is included.

Three games are mentioned in the rules; Jugger, Picture Lotto and Buss. The former is the main game, the Lotto game has nothing to do with the traditional Lotto game, and there are no rules (in my set) to the game of Buss..

Players ask each other for cards in a set they already have at least one card in that set in their hand. In Jugger, the object is to collect the most sets. In Lotto, the object is to claim the most cards by answering correctly when a question is read out.

General Notes from the rules;
Picture Cards
At the top of each picture card there is the name of a place where missionaries are working. In the game these places are called 'Juggers', the phonetic spelling of 'Jugah', a Hindustani word meaning 'place' or 'post'. Where a place is not well known and the pronunciation is difficult, phonetic spelling is given.

Map Cards
These are the Key Cards. Each map gives the names of the Juggers (marked by a heavy dot) in the set.

Question Cards
All the question cards are essential for Picture Lotto.

name: Was ist Was: Junior – Pferde & Ponys
description:
What do horses like to eat? What things do you need for horse care? What can be discovered in the paddock?

In Was ist Was - Junior: Pferde & Ponys, forty cards show everything that girls want to know about horses in ten different topics. These forty cards are first revealed at the start of the game, then hidden. A player draws a topic card – say, horse care – which will show 3-5 items that are on individual cards. Players try to remember where these items are and reveal them; with each success, a player moves her horse pawn one space forward on the track. Whoever reaches the goal line first wins!

name: Sport-a-Crest
description:
Place the 24 picture cards around the room where guests can easily see them. Players must look at the images and write down the sport suggested on their answer sheet.

The most correct answers, wins.

name: Grabbit!
description:
All players start with 8 cards.
On your turn, you roll the dice to see if you have to give, take or lose cards of the appropriate character.
At random times, the board will 'laugh' & you must then grab one of the highlighted character figures.
Any players that succeed in this will then score the matching cards in their hand.
Play to an agreed upon number of 'grabs'
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Dice, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Trippel
description:
"The game with three pieces"

Old Swedish boardgame published by Brio. An abstract strategy game for 2-4 players, it's reminiscent of Halma while also featuring Checkers-like piece elimination using rock-paper-scissors mechanics. Everyone has three pieces: "Hunter", "eagle" and "snake". The goal is to move as many of your pieces as possible across the board. You can move your pieces left, right and forward, but never backwards, and diagonally only when jumping over other pieces. Hunters can kill eagles when jumping, eagles can kill snakes and snakes can kill hunters.

Because of the elimination mechanic, the winner is the player who reaches their target corner with the most pieces remaining (in case of a tie, the one who got there first). Unlike most similar games Trippel also supports a 3-player variant, though no specific rules for this are given.

Likely date of publication: 1950's-'60s.

name: Rice Krispies Pop Game
description:
A promotional card game from Kellogg's.

A set collecting game with everyone playing at once. You call out cards you have available to swap (but not the colour) and you try to do a deal with a player who is calling out a letter you need (but, of course, it might be the wrong colour but you don't know that until you add the card to your hand.

When you have a set of three cards (that spell POP) you shout out "Pop!" and lay down the set face-up. The game stops whilst your set is checked as valid and then starts again.

The winner is the first player to lay down all their cards in valid sets.

Really, this is a simpler form of Pit.

name: Crêpes Party
description:
Each player roll the dice and move around the board to bring together the different ingredients of the pancake batter.
Once "milk shed", "flour weighing" and "broken eggs" are collected it's time the frying pan in hand to be the cleverest to blow up pancakes in a limited time.
But beware! There can be surprise on some squares on the board.

Winner is the player to make 15 pancakes.first.

Contents:

game board,
4 colored pawns,
1 die,
1 hourglass
12 cards ingredients
double-sided skillet,
a pancake,
crepe 60 tokens.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Mad Hatters: The Mad-Cap Feel It and Find It Game
description: Following instructions from the Mad Hatter cards, players attempt to remove the corresponding object from the brim of their own cap (special caps included). However, players are allowed to identify each object only by touch--no looking is allowed. If a player can correctly name the object, only then may they remove it. If a player removes the wrong object, they must put it back on their cap and pick up another object to add to their cap. The object is to be the first player to identify and correctly remove eight objects.

name: All About Charlotte
description:
Each player visits the shops and businesses and collects cards as detailed on their shopping list. The first to return home to their residence with the travel cards for all the locations on their list, wins.

The locations are real businesses in Charlotte, and this game was made as a promotional item for the area.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Das kleine Ich bin ich: Würfelwettlauf
description:
The classic children's story Das kleine Ich bin ich tells the story of a little animal that looks similar to many other animals – yet because it's not identical to any of them, it questions its origins and place in the cosmos until it comes to the realization that "I'm not just anyone – I AM ME!"

In Das kleine Ich bin ich: Würfelwettlauf, kids relive the exciting journey of this little animal discovering itself. Turn by turn, players have up to three rolls of the dice to determine where their character moves on the path and which animals they have showing on the dice. If a player moves his token onto an animal space (frog, horse, hippo, dog) matching a rolled die and the player has not yet added all of those matching animal parts to his critter, he adds one piece jigsaw-style. The first player to complete his animal wins.

name: Treble Eight
description:
Interesting party game. 24 cards all depict pictures of a cat, in eight sets of three identical pictures. Having said that there are eight sets of three, the pictures are all fairly similar. So good observation will be needed.

Place all the cards around a room. Each participating guest must look at the pictures during the party and make their observations. The first one to hand in all eight 'versions' of the pictures, wins.

name: Les 1000 Bornes des Inventions
description:
A Mille Bornes variant in which players must score maximum points by collecting the most inventions possible.

Draw a card to your hand, play or discard.

The game ends when one player has placed a series of six cards and he managed to shoot down six cards in his hand. The game also ends if no cards remaining in the deck is playable.
Each series reported scores up to 40 points, 10 bonus points triggering endgame, foul play by 10 points.
The winner is the first totaling 500 points after several parties

name: Don't Push Your Luck!
description:
Overview

Don’t Push Your Luck is an educational game, designed to incite discussion between the players about hemophilia, as well as help youth that live with the condition learn how to make decisions that are in their best interests. The game supports 2-4 players and is played over the course of 45 minutes. The game contains mechanisms that are not normally seen in educational games, and the effect is learning through engagement (fun). It also features attractive youth-friendly graphic design to further increase the accessibility, engagement and desire to play. Don't Push Your Luck combines light strategy of a family Euro with the fun and social exploration of a Party Game.

Just Another Day
Each player in Don’t Push Your Luck takes on the role of a child with hemophilia competing to have the most well balanced lifestyle, while trying to manage the risk they take in their activities. Players will be faced with the constant challenge of balancing of risk vs reward. The game is played over three rounds, each representing one full day.

There is a central board surrounded by 16 activity cards, that are randomly drawn before the beginning of each round. Each activity card represents a specific type of health: mental, social, emotional, and physical. In turn, players go around the board picking up activity cards and placing them in their player area. This represent them performing this activity. For example: on your turn you may choose to take the “hockey” activity card. Hockey provides 2 physical icons on it. These icons are later used to obtain “stars”, at the various “star spaces” around the board. The player with the most “stars” at the end of the game is declared the winner.

Inciting Discussion
Players must be mindful of the activities they choose to participate in during the day, because at the end of every round (3 total), each player tells a story about their day by describing each of the activities they selected. When the storyteller is finished telling describing each of their selected activities, the other players have an opportunity to discuss which of those activities they felt were not in the best interest of the story teller. The storyteller will often be trying to play down the risk of their selected activities, as they will be judged by the other players.

name: Jim Knopf's Abenteuerspiel
description: For 38 years Jim Knopf, his friend Lukas the railway man, Emma the locomotive and all their friends have taken children to Lummerland. This game leads players to three different locations, Lummerland, Kummerland and Mandala, and of course the kidnapped princess LiSi must be freed. The game is based on the concept in Michael Endes stories of cooperation and the joint efforts against adversities. The die brings luck into the game and Emma suspension, because players need to be in the company of Emma when the pass the finish line, but Emma tends to run away to another player in the last moment.

name: Ni Oui Ni Non: Nature
description:
In Ni Oui Ni Non: Nature, players need to answer questions as quickly as possible – but without saying "yes" or "no". Can they do it? Yes or no? Um, I mean, is it possible or will they fail?

Each round, one player picks a question card — with questions for a child or adult depending on who she intends to confront — then she chooses a victim and starts peppering the player with questions. If the victim ever utters "yes" or "no" when answering, the first player to slap the bell advances her token on the game board. If the victim hesitates too long or answers only with the same vague responses, such as "I don't know", slap that bell! If the victim makes it through the questioning without uttering the forbidden words, however, then she advances on the track. The first player to reach the center of the game board wins.

Ni Oui Ni Non: Nature includes more than 900 questions about animals and nature.
categories: Animals, Card Game, Party Game, Real-time

name: Pilomino
description:
Rounded doninoes what can place on top of each other forming a domino stack if half of the domino is same. If player can't play he must draw many dominoes he can play.

Player who drops the stack is eliminated from the game and puts his dominoes back to the supply.

The game ends when one player gets rid of all your dominoes. He is the winner.

name: Fótboltaspilið
description: From the publisher: A football (soccer) trivia game with 1800 questions in six categories. Those categories are: The English football, the Icelandic football, the European football, the National teams, On the field and 1 X 2. This game is for everyone who watches football, young and old. Up to six players or teams can play this game.

name: Wir gehen einkaufen
description:
Objective: collect most of those goods (12) placed on the board
learn the foods needed in the kitchen
- moving by turn -
simple 'Roll & Move' game
roll the die & move forward; ending on a card space collect it if available; game ends if all cards are taken.
remarks:
published ~ mid 50's in the GDR

name: Bombardo
description:
The game consists of a number of wire supports for a wire 'basket' into which is placed coloured balls. Each player chooses a colour. Then someone spins the 'top' which will career around and hit some of the supports and the ball in those supports might be dislodged. After the top has stopped, the player with the most coloured balls still on their supports, wins.

This would be a ridiculously short game if a winner is decided after just one spin, so it would be sensible to award a point to that player. Then the first player to get, say, five points would be the winner.

This game was made by the Lord Roberts Memorial Workshops, set up to give work and support to invalid soldiers after World War 1. Lord Roberts was a distinguished officer who had won a Victoria Cross in 1857.

name: Cliche Conflict
description:
Are you stumped by life’s deepest questions?
Would a Pirate beat a Ninja?
Could a Monkey dodge being eradicated by a Robot?
Can a Zombie avoid a Rampaging Viking?


Never fear, Purgatory Games is here to help you answer these pressing questions as we announce Cliché Conflict a fast paced game that brings the biggest stars of Geek Culture together for the craziest free-for-all battle.

Quick Overview:
Each player picks one of the icons and uses a deck of power and special cards to try to achieve one of 2 goals:

1) Exhaust all other players and have them leave the battle OR
2) Collect Special items that you are questing for!

The first player to achieve this wins the game. Simple!!!... or is it?!?

Comes in 3 sets:
- Pirate vs Ninja
- Monkey vs Robot
- Zombie vs Viking

Components (per set)
- 2 x 36 Card Faction Deck
- 33 Power per deck
- 3 Special per deck
- 1 Full Color Rule sheet
- 1 Tuck Box
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Hand Management, Set Collection, Variable Player Powers

name: Snooker-U
description:
The game simulates snooker through the playing of cards to represent shots. Scoring is the same as in snooker, with cards representing the different coloured balls being "potted". Breaks can be built, but the tactical use of safety shots, including snookers, will be needed to come out ahead over a series of frames.

Each player is dealt 5 cards, each of which represent a possible snooker shot: coloured balls score points, snooker and safety shots are defensive making it difficult for the opponent to "pot" a ball, whilst the fluke cards also score points acting as a "joker" for any ball. Each player lays cards until they can no longer continue their scoring break, refreshing their hand after every card laid. Their opponent then lays cards to score points in the same manner. The game ends once all the red and coloured balls have been potted as in the real game of snooker. The winner, as in snooker, is the player with the highest score. More typically, one would agree to play a match over a number of games.

name: Pictolingua
description:
From publisher's website

A vocabulary-learning game featuring the colorful illustrations of Swiss artist Karen Ichters. This game has 50 flashcards, 10 playing boards and 125 tokens to let you learn 50 words in 5 languages (the 4 languages of Switzerland plus English). Practice your language skills by trying to associate images with words. Young children can play an easier version using boards that already pair images with words. Older children and adults can play a more challenging guessing game using image-only boards. The first and lucky one to guess five successive images on the board shouts "Lingua" and wins!
categories: Children's Game, Educational, Memory, Trivia, Word Game

name: Reanimation: A Zombie Survival Game
description:
The city of Whitewater has suffered a great tragedy; for reasons unknown the dead have risen up from their graves and seek to feed upon the living. The city became overrun in a single night and the few remaining survivors now scavenge to survive during the day and barricade themselves safely away at night.

Players take control of a small group of three survivors who have managed to last the first few days of infection and even barricade a small building to hunker down for the night in. During the day you will send out two teams to scavenge for weapons, materials to build defenses with, supplies and even other survivors in order to prepare for the night; when 'they' come.

However, things would be easier if other groups of scavengers were not also competing for the same resources as you!
categories: Card Game, Horror, Print & Play, Zombies
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Open Drafting

name: Goldfield Gully
description:
In the spring of 1893, a torrential season of constant downpour and flash floods exposed gold-bearing quartz in a large gully in the Goldfield Mining District in the small mining town of Goldfield, Arizona. $25,000 worth of gold began washing down the street that ran through Goldfield. The mad dash was on to collect the gold before it was gone!

In Goldfield Gully players press their luck to uncover as much gold as they possibly can before the ever-watchful eyes of the local Marshal catches them in the act. Players must choose which buildings in the town of Goldfield they will dig for gold in front of, then hide from the Marshal. Every round the Marshal visits one building, forcing the player in that building to give up his entire treasure. Players may also forgo their turn to bank their treasure by giving up half to the Marshal and "banking" the other half. The player with the most gold at the end of ten rounds wins!

name: Tour of Switzerland
description:
A simple game linked to all things Swiss.

Each player is given 12 counters, 2 of which are put into a pool. The throw of a die determines how far you move. When landing on a numbered square, the player refers to the list of places corresponding with the number and pays to or receives from the pool, the numbers of counters stated.
When landing on a mountain pass - You must pay 1 counter to all other players. Customs squares will cost you 3 Counters!

The player who first reaches or passes No. 132 Basle and takes the pool, and the winner is the one with most counters.

Contents
1 Playing Board.
4 Playing Pieces.
Large Amount of Counters.
1 Die.
1 Set of Rules.

name: Knock Your Block Off
description:
Players build up a wall with many blocks in it. On their turn, they must knock out one block from the wall with the glove end of their bodger. The spinner determines the colour to go but the player chooses which particular block of that colour they want to try to remove.

The first player to dislodge any of their yellow blocks, loses the game.

name: Spelka
description:
Rare word game from around the turn of the 20th century. Devised at a "Famous London Literary Club", it was probably a new idea over 100 years ago.

52 cards all feature letters, each with a value that relates to the rarity of the letter in the English language (For example, an E would be 4, a Q would be 1, and so on). This value is important because if a player goes out whilst you still hold cards, then you give him the score of your unused cards - i.e. you are not penalised much for holding 'difficult' letters but you are if you hold common letters.

The game mechanic is simple. In a turn a player may lay as many cards as he wants but he must always have in mind a genuine word that could be spelt out eventually. For example, you might lay an L. The next player lays a T after the L (he is thinking of SALT). The next player might lay an I and an M after the T (he is thinking of ULTIMATE) and so on, until a player is challenged that there can be no such word with that array of letters (By the way, the letters must stay in the order they are laid, there is no rearranging letters). If challenged, a player must prove that he was thinking of a word, and if proven true, he receives payment (counters) from the others. If he was bluffing, he pays out counters to the persoin who challenged him.

When the game time is finished, the one with the most counters, wins.

By the way, in 1900 or so, they must have been aware of Analysis Paralysis because there is a fixed rule 'If you take longer than 30 seconds to play or pass, you forfeit your turn and must draw an extra card into your hand'.
And another oddity, how often are you told to enjoy your game - in Latin? The phrase Experientia Docet!, is used at the end of the rules
publishers: John Jaques of London, Milton Bradley

name: Yum Bingo
description:
As with traditional bingo, the goal is to be first to fill in the game card so as to reproduce the pattern selected at the beginning of the game.

Game Cards have boxes to fill in. Though they are all different, the game cards present all of the same combinations. On a total of 25 boxes, you will find 9 différent combinations.

Progress of the game; To get the desired combined value, all players have the right to roll the dice up to 3 times each turn. All six dice must be used for the first roll, but for the 2nd and 3rd rolls, the player has the choice of the number of dice to be rolled.

name: Top Banana Game
description:
Promotional game made by Waddingtons for Blue Label Fyffes Brand of bananas. Fyffes were the most famous supplier of bananas in Britain, mainly thanks to a catchy TV advert featuring the slogan "Unzip a Banana".

Top Banana is based on the Banana Industry, its pitfally and its successes. You travel around the banana-shaped board, buying plantations and then shipping your produce to the marketplace in Britain.

Although it is a familiar type of game, suggested by Monopoly, income is dependent on that which you can raise by making and selling (there is no "Collect 200 when you pass go").

The richest player wins if 'time' is called or if that player is the only one still in business.

name: Breakthrough
description:
A conversational card game in the vein of Scruples. The game features three levels of cards, blue, yellow, and red. The red cards are considered the most daring. Before the game, the players agree on which level cards to use (only blue, blue and yellow, or all three).

Each player draws one card per round. In turn, you can choose to answer the question by passing the card to another player, who reads the question back to you and you give your answer. Alternatively, you can challenge, where you will answer the question if another player answers it first. A third option is to pass and not answer the question.

Answered questions give 1 point for a blue card, 2 points for a yellow card and 3 points for a red card. After answering, each player can give you 2 bonus points if you revealed something they did not know about you. Alternatively, if another player feels you went all out to answer the question, displaying honesty and bravery beyond the call of duty, they can say "breakthrough" and you get 3 bonus points.

Game is played to a pre-determined time limit where the most points wins (or a set number of points can be used).

name: Pinocchio: The Merry Puppet Game
description:
The board, at first glance, looks like a Monopoly-type track but it isn't. This is a fairly traditional 'get to the end of the track' game.

Each player represents Pinocchio and receive 15 gold. You must start at the Carpenter's Shop and aim to arrive at the Cottage of the Talking Cricket. Movement is dictated by a spinner. If the spinner instructs you to take a card, you must obey the instructions on the card. If you are currently standing on a Safety Station you can ignore the card. The first to reach the cottage gains 5 gold and the winner is then the player with the most gold after all loans have been repaid.

A second version from Australia exists titled 'Walt Disney's Pinocchio the Merry Puppet Game' and mainly differs in the graphics on and in the box. Only scant reference on the back of the rules pamphlet shows that the game was manufactured in Australia by John Sands. The playing components and rules are the same except for the playing pieces, with the Australian version having simple coloured wooden discs. Dated 1939 the game promotes Disney's second animated movie which was released in February 1940.

name: Invisible War
description:
A pencil-and-paper game for up to 4 players. You need a 6 x 6 board to be placed in the centre of play. The board should be noted as A to F horizentally and as 1 to 6 vertically. It is then left in the centre as a quick reference for each player to know where each of their pieces are standing. Each player will have 3 Warriors and 1 King.

Each player takes a player sheet on which they allocate 10 points in total secretly to their three Warriors. Then the four pieces (including the King) are placed on the centre back-line nearest to each player.

Decide a random starter. A player can move and/or have a 'battle'. Warriors move 1 square in any direction. Kings move up to 2 squares orthagonally. Moving a piece is done by crossing out the old grid reference where it was and writing in the new grid reference being the square that that piece has just moved to. No two pieces of the same player can be on the same space and a piece cannot jump over a piece of the same colour.

Battle is done by announcing the square a piece is currently on (so before a move). The Battle takes place if one or more opposing pieces are on that square. The attacker announces the strength of his piece and the defenders announce their strength. The strongest piece wins and there are tie-breakers should their be a tie. After a Battle, the victor receives one point for each of his pieces so he gets the reward of stronger pieces for the rest of the game.

If a King is challenged, it immediately loses and that player is out of the game. The winner is the player with the last surviving king.

name: Fest im Sattel
description:
Fest im Sattel is a simple horse-themed roll-and-move game for children. It comes in a tin box whose lid is used as a board. The board shows a racecourse (shaped like an eight placed inside/onto an oval, with an extra circle inside one of the halves of the eight). Each player puts his/her horse token on the start space. Players take turns rolling the six-sided number die. If you roll a 1, 2 or three, you move your horse forward the corresponding number of spaces. Occupied spaces don't count, you just jump over them. If you roll a -1, you have to go back one space. Horses directly behind have to go back too. If you land on one of the special fields, you have to take a detour or lose a turn.

The player whose horse is the first to reach the finish line wins the game.

name: Mob Mania
description:
The gang bosses have met to divide up the town. Tempers turn and the talk turns nasty... It's a gang war!

The gangs have their instructions on a secret card and so they set off round the streets to take over two of the four city rackets.

Unoccupied property is taken over without a fight, but if a rival gangster has already taken it over and stayed in defense, it means risking a 'hit'.

Who knows the outcome of a duel with this hilarious armory? When a gang member initiates a hit on another player, they each draw a hit card add its number to your dice roll (one dice for each gang member and the Boss gets two dice), add up your score. The losing gang member(s) are 'hit' and no longer participate in the game.

Gangs collect tokens from the food, drink, gambling and money rackets in their headquarters to show the other gangs who is the boss.

The gang that survives to run the two sets of rackets on their objective cards is the winner.

name: Howzat!
description:
Each player draws an 11 x 10 grid. The columns are numbered and the rows lettered. In each of the ten columns the players distribute four 0's, three 1 's, two 2's, one 4, and an A for appeal in any order. The players then take it in turn to bowl an over. It is advisable for each player to record the outcome of his over on a spare grid.

Object
The player who scores the most runs before all ten of his appeals are located is the winner.

Play
The bowler picks a line of six contiguous squares as the over. They are announced by simply giving the starting square and the direction — e.g. E5/SE. The batsman plots this line on his grid and announces the total number of runs scored (i.e. the sum of the numbers passed through) and the number of appeals.
If a bowler thinks he knows the position of all ten appeals, he cries 'Howzat!' and reads out the positions. If any are wrongly placed the batsman draws up a fresh grid and continues anew. If the bowler is right, the batting side is all out. Obviously, if one side is still batting with more runs scored when the other side is all out, they need not continue. The bowler can then guess at the positions of the ten appeals, to discover the number of wickets down, and so determine the winning margin.

With a little ingenuity, limited-over and two-innings matches can be devised, together with individual batting and bowling figures, etc.

name: Diamino compétition
description:
Diamino Competition is a crossword game for up to 2-8 players, according to the rules of the game chosen.

The game includes 112 square, 110 carry a letter with a number indicating its point value. The last 2 squares representing a devil and can replace any letter. These devils have no point value.
The black boxes and the devils of different colors on the game board, create barriers or benefits.

1. The first player forms a word of eight letters long either horizontally or vertically with the first letter placed on the green box.
The player on the left continue and raises the number of squares they want to form, with the squares already in play, a new word.
2. The game should at all times, consist of complete words separated from each other. One or more voids must be present between two consecutive words
3. Exchanges. Each player may at any time redeem one or more squares of his hand, against an equal number of squares of the reserve. This exchange account for a ride. The square to the reserve (in reverse) are mixed again.
4. Benefits and barriers.
Black boxes found on the shelf boxes are prohibited. During the game, it is impossible to place a square.
Boxes with Diable Vert are in principle also prohibited. all-time, a player who needs to use them to form a word, may place a tile. In this case, as a penalty, he must take an extra tile to the reserve.

The winner is the player who succeeds in placing all his tiles first. The number of points acquired by him is the total of the numbers on squares that remain in the hands of other players.
If the winner ends the game by recovering a black box, the number of points is doubled.

name: Les Monsieur Madame le jeu
description:
The object of the game is to be the first to get 20 points by taking on challenges and being the fastest to find characters on the game board

In his turn player spins the arrow and draws a card of the color indicated by the arrow.

Cards represent one of the characters. The first one who puts his finger on the image of this character (exactly the same image!) on the gameboard, wins the card. He places it face up in front of him.

Some cards are "clues": these represent either a close-up, or the silhouette of a character. The first one who puts his finger on the image of the character wins the card
Ps! The character on the image must be exactly the same position!

Some cards are "challenges": only the player who drawn this card challenges with all other players to score point or not. If the award is made, the player keeps the card.

The end of the game:
The first to get a total of 20 points wins. Points (1 to 3, depending on the difficulty) are indicated on each card.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Party Game, Real-time

name: Das kleine Allgemeinwissensquiz
description:
Objective: know most of very generic questions

A small trivia game about knowlegde; with 100 questions and answers. The game itself is like a notebook (with spiral binding). Each page contains 2 questions and 4 nswers, the back side contains the correct answers with additional information.
Questions like:
Speed of light? When did the basic law of Germany become valid?

name: Die verrückte Bürokratie
description:
A commercial game for 'Deutsche BP AG'. Produced by Otto Maier Verlag, Ravensburg.

Each player draws some cards which determine the tiles they have to reach on the modular labyrinth-like board. Once a player has reached all the symbols stated on his cards he has to hurry back to his starting tile in order to win the game. However, the layout of the board is going to change through the course of the game by exchanging or switching/turning tiles - which of these actions take place is determined by the player in turn using a wheel as random generator.
mechanics: Modular Board, Network and Route Building, Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Tile Placement

name: Voleur d'étoiles
description:
The "thief of stars" in English is a cooperative game where players play together against the mage.

The mage Fedor has stolen all the stars. Player must recover and hang these in the sky before he regains his powers.

In his turn player rolls the dice and advance the number of boxes. There are squares where the stars could be hanged or bad squares where player help the mage regain his power.

The game ends in two ways:
Either the players have hung all the stars in the sky and win.
or the mage Fedor has regains his power and the players lose the game.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Roll / Spin and Move

name: All Aboard!
description:
All Aboard! is a pre-school game for 3 to 5 year olds. Match colours and shapes as you collect your passengers. Two games in one!
Game 1: Roll the colour spot dice to collect the coloured windows for your vehicles.
Game 2: Turn your vehicle over and all aboard as you spin the spinner and collect passengers in shaped windows.
The winner of each game is to fill up your train respectively.

Contents:
4 double-sided playing boards
24 square coloured cards
24 shaped passenger cards
Spinner
Colour spot dice
Dice cup
Rules

name: Troublesome Engines
description:
A game in the mould of Cootie, but this game requires 9 pieces to complete a picture of Thomas the Tank Engine or his friends. Super for little ones because the pictures take a jigsaw form and they learn sbout doing jigsaws whilst they are playing.

The winner is the one who completes their picture first.

name: Minden Soccer
description:
System for replaying individual football matches by minute-to-minute decisions. Statistics for all the 1990 World Cup teams are included, as it is a system for translating statistics from any match, so you can replay that great day for your team (unless your team is England, so there is no great day you can recreate!).

Each team is rated for ability in certain skills like 'shooting at goal' or 'passing the ball', 'movement' and so on. Once you decide the option you would like to take, you roll the dice and check on the ability. Sometimes you will retain possession and thus make the next decision, and so on, until you lose the ball and your opponent has the same choices for his team.

The one who scores the most goals, wins.

name: Engrenage
description:
Each player is an inventors who must be the first to patent three of his inventions. There is also consumers who goes around on a track schedule from store to store and pay money to its owners.

In his turn player rolls 2 dice, advances the number of spaces indicated and applies the effects of the square he stands:

He may earns the royalties were deposited at least one patent
He may buy or exchange different components to make a prototype or invention
Move the consumer on the trail of stores and pay royalties to its possessor


etc.

Once its patents obtained nationally, you have to pay for these and go to the finish. Try to be the first at finish with 3 obtained patents to be the winner.

name: Smuggler Bold
description:
Each player has a map overlaid with squares. One player is the Smuggler, the other is a Coastguard. Players start at oppositer ends of the map. Movement is governed by dice. Both players fill in the squares on the path they have taken that throw. Filled-in squares cannot be used again by the player who filled them in.

The objective is to avoid interception or to intercept, depending on which side you are on.

name: Generations
description:
Game that tries to encourage people into the hobby of Genealogy, ancestor hunting you might say.

Generations is a board game with playing method which uses logic reasoning (in this regard, very similar to Cluedo) to solve a mystery of family history. Players search 7 regions of the United States for their make-believe ancestors, U.S. birthplaces, careers and lifestyles.

The first player to complete a family history (i.e. work out which facts are hidden, by eliminating facts that have been revealed to that player), wins.

Several game options ensure that play never becomes boring and that different levels of skill can be achieved. Variations include:
Logic Reasoning: Adapt for the time you have and the playing skill levels by varying the number of search categories. .
Storytelling: At the end of the game, the winner can make up a story about the discovered ancestor's life using "facts" found during play. This variation develops imagination and communication skills.
True Family History: Introduce players to real family stories as they "travel" regions of the United States asking questions about their pretend ancestors, where they were born, how they may have lived and how they earned their living.

Contents;
playing instructions (for home and classroom)
game board
moving pieces
dice
cards
lifestyle tokens
career tokens
ancestor worksheets
realistic family tree charts

name: Top Tennis
description:
Statistical tennis game, especially designed to get a result quickly, thus making it possible to play an event in one evening. Over 200 players are rated.

Various statistics are provided (ability, ranking, serving, etc.), and a die is used to get a specific result for an action you have just attempted.

name: Sharad'
description:
Players form two teams and each team chooses speaker.
The two speakers are placed side by side and they draws a card. There are words on the cards and speakers must explain it to players with the charades preferably more accessible to their own team.

The first team that sets the correct answer scores one point.

The game length is established before the game (10 points or 15 minutes). Winner is the team with the most points.
categories: Card Game, Party Game, Word Game

name: Humphrey Cards
description:
A promotional pack of cards, with the four normal suits being replaced by Bottles, Arks, Humphreys and Jokes.

The rules to various games are given:
Bottle Up!
Happy Humphreys (this is a slight variant of Happy Familes)
Hello Humphrey (better known as Pairs)
Humphrey Patience
Humphrey Overboard

There are 52 cards plus a Joker. Each suit bears a symbol to match its name, but the 13th card in each suit is always a crown. The game was mailed to interested customers in a plain white box except for one side that invites the owner to enter his or her name.

Each card also bears the normal traditional suit and number so that the cards could be used to any other card game that you like.

name: Deplimo
description:
Deplimo is a word game for 2 to 4 players, where everyone plays their own tray. Player draw letters to form words on a special "meter metric" that folds and unfolds, which allows to vary the trays.

At start the dice is rolled to determine the shape of its route on which 25 letters can be played. The words must be joined by a common letter at intersections.
In his turn player draws 5 letters. When words can not be reached, it is possible to return a letter. Game ends if first player finishes his tray and then everbody counts their letters.

Player with the most letters is the winner.

name: Monopoly: Wien
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Vienna, in Austria.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Qwikstat Tennis
description:
Super fast statistical tennis game, so quick that an entire Wimbledon can be completed in one evening. Each player has certain skills (serving, etc) and these are accessed or avoided depending on dice rolls.

My set is dated 1992 and has 1200 player ratings from 1973 to 1992.

name: Hextrap
description:
Requirements: Paper and pencil. Match- sticks.

The board is a large hexagon,, divided as shown into 24 triangles. The size is such that matchsticks can be placed along the sides of the triangles. The large hexagon contains seven smaller 6-triangle hexagons, the centres of which are marked with large black dots.

One player is the 'mouse'. This is represented by a small coin which the player may place in any of the 24 triangles at the start of each game.

The other player is the 'cat' who attempts to trap the mouse in one triangle, by placing his matchsticks on the lines and gradually restricting the mouse's move-ments. His first move is to place a match anywhere on the board. The players then move alternately.

The mouse must move when it his turn. He may move to any triangle in the same small hexagon. That is to say he may move anywhere round the one dot. He may not cross over a matchstick.

Each player has two consecutive turns as the cat. He has 19 matchsticks which he may use on his two attempts to catch the mouse. He scores one point for each success. If he catches the mouse with 8 matchsticks in his first turn, he has 11 matchsticks for his second turn.

The first player to score 9 points is the winner.

The cat can always win with his first turn, but to get a lead over his opponent he must win and still leave himself enough matchsticks to win the second game as well. The best technique for the cat is usually to place his first two matches in opposite directions from the centre of the board as if to divide the board in half. He then ensures that the mouse is confined to one side of this division and in the smallest possible area.

The mouse, on the other hand, tries to keep to the largest possible open space, and to triangles where he has a choice of several dots round which he may move.

name: Clobber
description:
This amusing little two-player game can be enjoyed by young and old alike. All that is required is a 7 x 7 squared grid, four playing pieces per player, and a die.

The pieces start in the positions as shown in the diagram (squares 0 and X) and the object is to manoeuvre the pieces so as to occupy two opposite centre squares (A-A or B-B in diagram).

Players move in turn according to the roll of the die as follows:
1 or 4 = 1 square,
2 or 5 = 2 squares
3 or 6 = 3 squares

Movement is only allowed in a vertical or horizontal direction. It is not permissible to occupy the centre square, nor is one able to jump over another piece. Also only one piece can occupy any one square and it is obligatory to move the full number of squares if possible. The highlight of the game occurs when a piece lands upon a square occupied by an enemy piece. The owner of the moving piece must shout in a clear, loud voice the word "Clobber". Having complied with that rule, he may remove the enemy piece and replace it anywhere on the board that he wishes, preferably as far from its target as possible.

This quick, simple game is well worth a try, it can become quite compulsive.

name: Synchro
description:
Played upon a nine-by-nine squared grid, Synchro is an abstract game containing a number of very interesting concepts. Reference to the diagram will show that the board has four black squares, known as Vantage Points, and two Castles.

Each of the two players begins with twelve playing pieces of three types.- Lumps, Blobs and Things. Each piece also bears a number from 1 to 6 and a pair of pieces with the same number constitute a unit. A player's four Lumps consist of two units numbered 1 and 2, his four Blobs are units 3 and 4, whilst the four Things are 5 and 6.

The board is placed with a Castle in front of each player, who then places his pieces anywhere in the three rows nearest to him, one piece per square. On a turn, a player must move one of his units. Pieces may not move onto or over an occupied square, except when capturing an opposing piece. The actual moves that can be made are as follows:
(1) Where both members of a unit are on the board but neither is on a Vantage Point, both pieces are moved one or two squares in any direction, but both must move the same distance and direction. It is this feature that gives the game its name.
(2) Where both pieces are on the board with either or both on Vantage Points, they can move as above but independently of one another.
(3) One piece of a unit on the board, not a Vantage Point, moves one space in any direction.
(4) One piece on a Vantage Point, one or two squares in any direction.

Pieces may only capture certain other pieces as follows:

Lumps (1 and 2) capture Blobs (3 and 4).
Blobs (3 and 4) capture Things (5 and 6).
Things (5 and 6) capture Lumps (1 and 2).

When captured, a piece is removed from the board and may only return under one circumstance; if it is the last piece of any one type, a player may exchange one of his pieces in play for the captured piece, which is immediately swapped with it and placed on the board. The object of the game is to move a piece onto one's opponent's castle, or to capture all of his pieces. At first, this may seem very similar to a hundred other games, however, the synchronised movement adds a new dimension.

name: Pick-a-Pair
description: From the publisher's website: Players or teams compete to list familiar pairs of words or phrases that fit a category for each round. For example, “salt & pepper” fits the category “Food or Cooking”. Score points for pairs not listed by other players. Score extra points for pairs that rhyme, pairs that use the same word twice, triples (three main words or phrases like "red, white & blue"), or quadruples (four main words or phrases). Play 4-8 rounds in a game.

name: Blind 31
description:
In this card game players try to replace cards in their hand of three cards so that it gets close to the target of 31 points. The twist is that they can't look at their initial three cards unless they are discarded in favour of other, hopefully better, cards.

Pagat.com says:

This game by Gary Woitzik combines the objective of 31 (Scat, Blitz) with a play mechanism similar to "Golf" (the card game). It uses a special 65-card pack which consists of the 52 cards of a standard Anglo-American deck plus 13 cards with special functions reminiscent of those found in UNO and other games: 2 Wild, 2 Reverse, 2 Skip, 5 Take All, 1 Scramble and 1 Swap.

name: Caperucita
description:
Caperucita is a card game for children.

Beware the wolf! In Caperucita the players run the forest path to grandmother's house and collect as many flowers as they can while they avoid the wolf.

The aim of Caperucita is to collect as many flowers while avoiding you catch the wolf. You must play your cards with the ability to earn points for each pair of flowers formed and ensure that the wolf catch the other players. The game ends when the deck runs out of flowers or when the wolf has caught all the players less
to one.



====================Caperucita es un juego de cartas para niños.

¡Cuidado con el lobo! En Caperucita los jugadores recorren el
