To do this, they need to spot the tiny details on these critters — a light bulb on a firefly, a grub playing the guitar, a caterpillar munching on a snack — and cover them with a matching leaf in their hand.

name: Early Pacific Battles
description:
This game kit published by Bruce Moore covers all aspects of 1942 battles in the Pacific. Air to Air, Air to Surface (fixed installations and naval task forces), Naval Surface and Land Combat are all treated as well as multi-player strategic combat embracing all of the above. Scenarios are included for the significant engagements as well as several hypothetical meetings, for example, War Plan Orange III battleship duels and surface action off Malaya had Prince of Wales and Repulse escaped air strikes.

The game kit aspect is the supply of hundreds of small coloured blocks to which unit details must be glued. Torpedo tracks and cloud formations for strategic game weather handling must be cut out.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Nautical, Wargame, World War II

name: Mediterranean (fan expansion for Ticket to Ride: Rails and Sails)
description:
This map is an unofficial fan made expansion. Symbols & Graphics Copyright © 2004-2015 Days of Wonder, Inc. Produced with permission of Days of Wonder, for non-commercial use only.

This follows the principles of the Ticket to Ride - Rails and Sails game on a special board with special cards and rules. The object of the game is to gain the most points by travelling various routes and outwitting other players. You will need the train ,ship and harbour pieces and the train and ship cards from Ticket to Ride - Rails and Sails base game.

There is an extra set of Tourist cards for the cities, each with a value to be earned by visiting that city. These cards are dealt/picked up alongwith tickets in the same quantity and with the same 'keep/dispose' rules.

The 9 bonuses give you extra points.

There are many new options in the rules: exchange all your cards at the start but keep all the new ones: discard 5 cards and pick up 5 new ones, as your turn: earn extra points: and many more. You can also call time when your wagon stock reaches 3, if you want, giving you the advantage of stopping other players completing tickets.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fan Expansion, Print & Play

name: Dexikon: Alternate Letters Expansion
description:
A small expansion that consists of 5 Expansion Cards.

These five red/orange cards have the "Alternate Attack" ability, and feature the letters M and Z, and intended to replace the "Attack" cards in the original game.

These cards allow players to activate an ability to hurt other players, for example by forcing them to discard cards.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Word Game
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Spelling

name: Corporate Ladder
description:
Become CEO by tricking your coworkers!

Corporate Ladder is a card game of deal-making, bluffing, and office humor for 2-6 players. Negotiate with your co-workers on what performance review cards you each will play. Equal cards give you both a Promotion and move you up the corporate ladder, but be careful: a worse card will give you a Warning and push you towards an early retirement.

Think your rival is going to betray you? Sneakily call in a favor from your rolodex by playing a business card to gain an unfair advantage.

Dole out enough Warnings to get your competitors fired or earn enough Promotions to rise to CEO and win the game!

--Description from the designer:
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Negotiation, Player Elimination

name: My First Memory: What Animals Eat
description:
My First Memory: What Animals Eat is a tile matching game featuring various animals and the foods they eat. Younger children can play it as a simple matching game, finding pairs of identical tiles, while older children might enjoy slightly more difficulty by matching animals to the foods they eat.

Players begin by placing the tiles in rows, picture side down. The first player takes his turn by flipping over two tiles. If they are a match, he keeps the tiles and takes another turn. If the tiles do not match, the player returns them to their face down positions, and the next player takes her turn. Play continues until all of the tiles have been matched and collected. The player with the most tiles wins.

name: Liga
description: Each player represents a football (soccer) club and moves a token up and down a short track, signing pro players and drawing event cards. When two players meet on the track going in opposite directions they face off in a match, the outcome of which is determined through rolling dice based on the players signed to each club. Some matches also trigger betting. Victory points are accumulated by winning or drawing matches, and the game is played to a number of points agreed on beforehand.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Whim
description: Whim is a risky word game in which location is everything. Players race to find words with letters that they choose, and the letters must appear either at the beginning, in the middle, or at the end of the word based on the die roll that round.

name: Telefoot
description:
Recreation of a soccer game.
Teams are formed by 11 players.
Rules are simple.
Game for 2 players.
Field is divided into square areas.
There is a maximun number of players allowed per area.
Passes, driblings and shots to goal are checked by a die roll.
In advanced game there are action points for movement, an for dribbling.

name: Olympia 1988
description:
This is a compilation of 12 sports games. Some of them were available separately as part of the "ZDF-Sportstudio-Linie".
The games included are:

Schwimmen (tile-placement-game)
Zehnkampf (board game)
Schießen (tactical board game)
Boxen (card game)
Radrennen (board game)
Reiten (board game)
Olympia*Quiz
Handball(boardgame)
Leichtathletik (dice game)
Tennis (board game)
Hockey (board game)
Fußball (board game)
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Sticko
description:
Sticko is a game by David Parlett, designed to be a solitaire game of his similar game Stucco. In this game, you are trying to build up a sequence of cards based on these three resrictions:

You can only play a higher rank of the same suit, a lower rank of the opposite suit of the same colour, and the same rank of either of the opposite colour suits.

name: Rise of the Elders: A Cthulhu World
description:
A Tabletop Game based on the Cthulhu mythos, featuring:

- RPG-based character creation for every new game: Create your unique character each time using one of the 6 sheets (10 with the kickstarter edition), each with bonuses, maluses and a point on one feature. Will you focus on Strength, Agility or Resistance ?

- Modular Board: Create your own path, each step into the unknown could be your last, but be aware of the empty hexagons you create while building the map. Cthulhu wants them, Cthulhu wants your defeat.

- Storytelling: Each new tile is supported by a new story, each story has two choices and each of them leads to one of 6 outcomes (3 good ones, 3 bad ones) resulting in 1080 astonishing possibilities. Each choice is based on your character's features and your luck.

- Uniquely designed miniature models for every monster in the game (Heir of Cthulhu, Shub-Niggurath, Azatoth and Yog-Sothoth) and for every character.

- Enemies among Friends: In each game you play, you'll never know if the player by your side is a friend or a foe. It starts as a cooperative game, but one of your "friends" might be a cultist for one of the Ancients.

- Turn Based: You don't have much time, you need to find the site of the ritual trying to bring a Ancient Ones into our world through a portal. You only have a few turns to do it!

- Equip Yourself: As in any RPG game, your character can use weapons, like a Machinegun or an Axe, find marvellous objects, like powerful Talismans, or outlive danger through the use of protective gear.

- The Goal: If you're one of the investigators of the occult, your goal is to close all the Ancient portals, but if you're one of the cultists, your goal is to complete the ritual to bring your Ancient One on Earth.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Role Playing, Storytelling, Tile Placement, Variable Phase Order

name: A Game of Seasons
description:
ADORN YOUR TREE WITH THE SAME COLOUR CANOPIES TO WIN!

Throw the two dice to get new canopies for your tree, but watch out you might lose some!The first player to complete their tree in one colour wins.
COMPONENTS:
4 wooden trees, bare,
20 coloured wooden canopies (5 for each season),
1 cardboard basket,
2 wooden dice
INSTRUCTIONS:

The first player to complete their tree with 5 canopies of one season (colour) wins. All of the 20 canopies are placed in the basket and each player takes a bare tree. The youngest player goes first by picking up a canopy and placing it on their tree. The game then continues in a clockwise direction. A player throws the two dice that show the ACTION to perform (e.g. take a new canopy and put it on your tree) and WHERE to take the canopy from (e.g. from one of the other player's trees) or WHAT to take (e.g. a green or pink canopy). The game ends when a player, the winner, completes their tree with all 5 canopies of the same season (same colour).

name: Woomal
description:
Woomal is an educational cooperative board game published internally by The Guides and Scouts of Finland as part of the 2009-2011 Finnish-Senegalese environmental project of the same name (the word means 'development' in the Wolof language of Western Africa). Although the game contains a lot of snippets of text describing basic environmental problems and solutions around Senegal, the actual game play is language independent producing simple, thematically imaginable situations which the players can use as a node of thought for discussions and learning.

During the game, players move their pawns around a highly abstracted map and use combinations of knowledge cards in three colours to remove corresponding combinations of problem markers from affected areas. Starting with just one card, players can acquire new ones by collecting enough markers from the map or by going to the education center. The three different colours represent three generic categories of issues: water, the natural environment and human activities.

Because the problems are often too complicated or become too large, players need to work together and plan their turns carefully so that their characters can work together in the game and share their knowledge and effort in the most effective way. Due to the randomly allocated problem markers giving players new objectives and blocking movement on the map, the game is constantly presenting small, changing spatial puzzles for players to solve. Separate game sessions can develop in very different ways and provide varied narratives to think about.

Players win the game by removing all the larger problems from the map or by each player collecting enough knowledge cards so that everyone is prepared for the future. The players lose if all the villages on the map are covered with problem markers or if too many larger problems accumulate anywhere on the map. Woomal could be described as a very simple version of Pandemic, played on a grid of hexagons.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Grid Movement, Set Collection

name: Ik Vertrek
description:
Do you have success abroad?
Are you curious whether a foreign adventure can wager success?
In this family game the goal is to move abroad and start a new life.
Survive obstacles, learn a new language, adjust to a different culture.
The players move on a path via a roll & move mechanic and have to handle events and do tasks depending on which spot they land.
The player who reaches the finish first is the winner.

name: Bushido: Araka
description:
The latest slave of Yurei, having been raised by Kato ‘the puppet master’ now takes on any and all opponents of the Cult. Enemies that fall before his onslaught become the gruesome tools of his trade.

Blister contains one miniature, 50mm base and full colour profile card.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting, Miniatures
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Tid til tal
description:
This game is designed for use in primary school, but is also suitable fort originally to play with numbers at home.

The idea behind the game is that when the child playing and having fun, then it is also easier to learn. Therefore, in these games emphasized that it should be both fun and educational at the same time.

Game contains 12 different small games like memory game, where combining "actual numbers" with "number of dots" on the tiles. Dice rolling with addition and/or subtraction. The game focuses on getting familiar with numbers and light addition and subtractions

name: Leg Lær Læs
description:
Leg Lær Læs focuses on the 120 most frequently occurring words in the Danish language. Today it is widely recognized that children who master these words are far easier to learn to read and write.

The game consists of 16 small games and game with increasing difficulty that all strengthens children's language comprehension and increase their reading speed. Leg Lær Læs use different learning styles, so there are games and games for both children who would like to sit still, and those who want to move while they have fun learning.

name: GDPR Board Game
description:
ISACA made a goose game to support the awareness raising on the European data protection legislation (General Data Protection Regulation).

As in any goose game the players move the meeple forward by ruling a die. The position of the meeple determines what the player must do: answer an open question (red), answer a "yes/no" question, hold, jump forward, drop back,...

name: Troll Bridge
description:
Description from the publisher:

In Troll Bridge you play an intrepid messenger competing against other messengers to deliver their messages across a very unstable, Troll-infested bridge. But these aren't your normal Trolls, that would be boring.

There are two types of Trolls, Ug Trolls which aren't all that smart and would rather smash the bridge and create holes to avoid than get into any kind of friendly small talk. Then there are their smarter counterparts, the Tollosophers which want to chit chat and you have to answer their questions to pass.

Along the way you can collect Treasure that can help you fight Ug Trolls, hinder your opponents, patch the bridge, and even swap Ug Trolls for Trollosophers and many other interesting and sometimes useful things.

Just make sure not to die along the way.

Players take turns moving their messengers along the bridge one space at a time. Each space reveals a tile that indicates if they fight an Ug Troll, a Trollosopher, or if they have found some treasure and possibly nothing, which grants an extra move.

Players must navigate around holes in the bridge created by Ug Trolls. They can risk death by jumping over a hole and hoping they don't fall through the rickety bridge on the other side. In some cases this may make sections unpassable and players will have to go around those sections.

Defeating the Ug Trolls is determined by dice roll to damage the Ug Trolls. Each turn the Ug Troll remains, the player cannot advance and he knocks out sections of bridge. Defeating a Trollosopher is done by successfully answering their trivia questions. While they remain, they just keep a player from advancing.

Play continues until one player successfully reaches the end of the bridge. Once that happens, the game is over and the winner is determined by score. Players score points for finishing first, and for each Troll defeated as well as any treasure they have remaining.

name: Paseo
description:
Paseo is a dice-rolling race game akin to backgammon. Players create a starting board at the beginning of the game.

Paseo is published in two editions: one with ceramic tiles and another with paper tiles. Each edition includes a Zodiac A and Zodiac B version with differently colored pieces and tiles, allowing for games with up to four players if the two versions are combined.

name: Zakgeldspel: Kaartspel
description:
This is the cardgame variant of the popular boardgame by the same name.

Players are saving money to buy a new bicycle. They earn money by doing easy chores or harder tasks.

Each player has a row of 4 tasks in front of them for the other players to do. Hidden below one of the four cards/tasks lies a "lazy" card. The later is to be avoided as this costs the player money when chosen. Can you bluff and choose wisely?

First player to gather €20 wins the game.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Children's Game, Economic

name: Bushido: Kairai Villager
description: Where she comes from, who she is or who she was will probably never be known. The chance of anything being left of the person she used to be seems unlikely. Unquestioning, she ambles along thoughtlessly, slowly and yet relentlessly to do the bidding of her dark masters. No one is safe from the depravities of the Cult.
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Wallet Civ in Space!
description:
Description from the designer:

Wallet Civ in Space! is a 9 card pen and paper game. Print or write out the 9 instruction cards, and on the reverse of each card, you will create your space mining empire.

Each turn, shuffle the deck, set aside 2 of the cards not in play this turn, play out 4 cards "space" side up to build upon, and then the remaining 3 cards "instruction" side up to see what you can do! Then shuffle up the 9 cards again.

Please see https://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/1577111/wallet-civ-9-ca... for rules.

name: Lotus Dimension
description:
Lotus Dimension is a tabletop role-playing game (RPG).

Players have to solve all the challenges the
game thrown at them using nonviolent means?
What if a game drew on amazing sci-fi and fantasy storytelling while also incorporating principles of nonviolence inspired by peaceful protests, historical leaders and the tenets of peaceful philosophical practices?

And what if it offered players a way to visualize and role-play solutions to wildly imagined problems, responding to and replacing violence and weaponry with empathy and ingenuity?

name: Bottle Flip
description:
Bottle Flip is a dexterity game where players attempt to flip a bottle onto a target according to different challenge cards. Players move along a scoring track after successfully completing flip challenges.

Types of Bottle Flip challenges include:
Individual Challenges
Face-To-Face “Flip Offs”
Group “All Out Flip Outs”
Create Your Own Challenges

Challenge examples:
-Flip and land a bottle using only your elbows
-1 attempt to land 6 bottle flips before you blink

name: Picture It!
description:
Ready...Set...Sketch!
Quickly draw sketches based on a category like "Board game parts". You will go crazy tryimg to read your partner's mind and sketch at the same time. But,when time is up you and your partner check to see if your sketches match. When you see the ridiculous sketches, you'll see there's nothing sketchy about how much fun it is to play!

name: The Big Game: African Savannah – Wildlife Safari Adventure Board Game
description:
Go on a jungle safari and sight wild animals. This game is just about that. You may come across animals 'endemic to' - found only in - that place as well as other wild animals found in that biosphere. The game covers vast biospheres that are spread across a few hundred square kilometres.

You score points from the animals you sight on the game cards. The rare or difficult-to-find animals get you higher points. The game ends when all cards are drawn. However, we have gamers who have developed their 'own' ways to end the game. You can do it too. The player with the highest score is the winner.

This game is almost entirely controlled by the dice. Ideal for children aged 6 years or more.

While safari-goers share their experiences eagerly with other fellow safari-goes in a 'real' one, players swap their hands in this game. Or you could be punished with a missed turn if you overspeed or make too much noise and disturb wildlife.

There are basic strategy bits too. For instance, how you would make use of the special cards: the Paapa card or the Kaadoo card. You can use these cards when you need them, you do not have to play these cards immediately. Or you have the 'turnaround' card that lets you make a complete u-turn and go in the reverse direction. You can play this card if you appear to be leaving the forest in the next few rounds.

The safari course is fixed and you cannot go off that. But, there are a good number of elements from the game that make it refreshing every time you play it. For example, on-board elements such as 'move to the nearest water body', bonus card pick from an alarm call.

We have tried to recreate the experience for those who are completely new to safaris as well as seasoned safari-goers. The game board tries to capture the signature of the terrain - arid, dull or lush green as the case may be.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Environmental, Exploration, Party Game

name: Green Hornet
description:
A Card game for 2-4+ players on a Green Hornet Theme.

Players share a common deck consisting of 8 card types:
G = Green Hornet
K = Kato
B = Black Beauty
V = Villain
T = Thugs
P = Plot
I = Investigation
S = Special

Each turn has 4 Phases:
1. Pulp Phase
- Draw 2 cards from the deck.
2. Action Phase
- Discard one card from your hand and take an action dependant on the card type.
3. Installment Phase
- You may Solve a Case to do this you must do the following:
Reveal 1 Villain card, 1 Thug card, and 1 Plot card. You may also play a Special card for its Crime Points.
- Add up the Total Crime points from the 3 or 4 cards played.
- Next play 1 Green Hornet card, 1 Kato card, 0-1 Beauty cards, 0-1 Investigation cards, and 0-1 Special cards.
- Add up the total Hero points of these cards.
- The Hero points must equal or exceed the value of the Crime Points.
- Gain Victory Points equal to the number of Crime Points played.
- Discard all revealed cards.
4. Cliffhanger Phase
- If you Solved a Case this turn, fill your hand to 7 cards.
Max hand size is 9 cards. Discard excess cards.

The game ends when the deck has been gone through twice.
The player with the most Victory Points wins.

name: Game of Puss in the Corner
description:
The game includes 32 cards with a small instruction booklet on how to play.
The playing cards are illustrated with prowling pussy cats, hungry rats, and sneaky mice.

Players begin with placing the four special marked Puss in the Corner cards in the center of the table, corner to corner.

The dealer then takes one card for each player playing from the pack and sets it to the side for using at the end of the game. The bottom card should be a Puss card. Puss cards are numbers 23 through 28.

After the remaining cards are all dealt to the players, players take turns placing cards to the Puss in the Corner cards. Top cards are turned over from the player’s face down pile and placed in the following ways.
If a player turns over an Even numbered rat or mice card, he plays it to an Even numbered Puss card in the center of the table. An Odd numbered rat or mice card is played to an Odd numbered Puss card.

If a player turns over a single Puss card, he can take the pile that states the either Odd or Even card. A Puss card depicting two cats can take any pile. If there aren’t any piles to take, then the player just plays the card to the matching Even or Odd pile.

When the players are out of cards, they take from the dealer’s set aside pile. Once these are all gone, then the winner is decided upon.

The winner is the player who captured the most mice and rats.

name: Game of Life's Mishaps
description: A die is rolled to determine movement. The player’s game pieces move around the board accordingly. Thirty two disc counters are also part of the game. Divided evenly among players at the start of the game, these discs are used either to pay or receive from a pool. Landing on a mishap space, requires a player to pay two discs to the pool. Landing on other specific spaces, a player may receive three from the pool or pay only one. The winner of the game is the player with the most discs at the end.

name: Jääkiekkopeli
description:
Description from the rulebook:

Jääkiekkopeli LÄTKÄ is totaly new type of a quiet icehockey game for all the icehockey fans, players and beginners. Using the board, it is easy to learn the rules and tactics of the "real game". Icehockey game is an implementation of the "real game" to be played with a dice.

The aim of the game is to make more goals then the opponent. This happens by dribble or passing the buck from player to player on the opposing goal and then make a goal shot.

Players roll two dice and move one pawn for the compined sum or two pawns, one for each die. Player can also pass the buck, then the buck is moved with the same rules. Though it stops if it makes a contact with a pawn. If it is active players, the rest of the dice count can be used to move that pawn with the buck.

name: ZEALANDIA Trading Card Game
description:
Description from the publisher:

Introducing the ZEALANDIA Trading Card Game! Your students will have a blast learning about New Zealand bird life through addictive gameplay and trading. This game is designed to be fun and engaging while teaching students about our many manu (birds) and how to identify them.

Each bird's card has three ability ratings that range from 0 to 9, 0 being the lowest and 9 being the highest. The uppermost ability rating is flight (F) followed by camouflage (C) and special (S). The numbers reflect the bird’s abilities for each category. ‘Special’ indicates how unique or special that bird is to New Zealand.

1. Each player starts with an odd number of cards in their hand.
2. Before the game starts each player may place down one environment card.
3. The youngest player starts by calling flight (F) camouflage (C) special (S) or night time (which is all three numbers added together.)
4. Each player places a card face down on the table.
5. Name your card and flip it face up.
6. The player with the highest rating for that ability wins and leaves their card face up on the table and the loser places theirs face down. If the rating is even, then the player who didn’t call the round wins.
7. It is now the other player’s turn to call and start a new round.
8. Once there are no more cards left, count the number of win cards you have in your pile.

If you want to play the advanced version, read the abilities on the cards and use them when you turn your card face up. If a card talks about the pile, these are the cards you have down on the table.
categories: Animals, Card Game, Collectible Components, Educational, Environmental, Math

name: Blaggards
description:
A co-operative booty lootin' game with a splash o' betrayal.

Blaggards is a party game for six to eleven players. A band of pirates are attempting to open six locked chests of booty. The chests can only be unlocked with a specific combination of keys - keys that have been scattered amongst the players. Alas, there is a hidden team of Blaggards! The Blaggards want to ruin the pirates day and keep the booty locked up.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Variable Player Powers, Voting

name: The Muppet Show
description:
A card game for 2-4 players based on The Muppet Show! The game represents one Episode.

Players share a common deck. Cards are of one or a combination of types: Character (C), Event (E), Bonus (B) or Special (S)
Plastic discs are used to keep track of Act (victory) Points.
To start 5 cards are dealt to each player.

Players take turns with each turn comprising 4 Phases:
1. Dressing Room Phase
- Draw 1 card from the top of the deck or discard and put it in your hand.
2. Backstage Phase
- You may play (discard) a special card in this phase to activate its special ability.
3. Act Phase
- You may play an Act this phase. An Act requires 2-6 specific cards to be played (revealed) according to the Act Chart (comprising 18 different acts).
- Act Points are scored as listed on the Chart for completing the Act (2-6 points dependant on the act).
- Score an extra Act Point if you were the last player to also play an act.
- Each Act in the Act Chart can only be claimed once per game.
- Bonus cards can be played along with the required cards of an Act. Each Bonus card played is worth 1 Act Point. Some Bonus cards give an extra Act Point for specific Acts.
4. Finale Phase
- Max hand size is 7 cards. Discard excess cards.

WINNING
The game ends when 8 (of the 18) Acts have been played. The player with the most Act points is the winner. If tied, the player with the most acts wins.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Apotheosis of Technology
description:
A card game for 2-4+ players with the theme of Technological Advancements of the next 1000 Years.

Players share a common set of Victory Tokens (VT), Research Tokens (RT) and Energy Tokens (ET).

There are 10 small decks with each deck representing a century. Each card represents a new technology, event, discovery, or social change. When played, cards will cause players to gain VT, RT, ET, steal cards from other players, increase hand size etc.

Each player starts with 10 VT and is dealt 2 cards from the 21st Century Deck. (Disaster cards are discarded and redrawn).

Players take turns with each turn comprising 4 Phases.

1. Resource Phase

Gain 1 Research Token and 1 Energy Token


2. Discovery Phase

Draw 1 card from the current deck (the oldest deck that still has at least 1 card in it). If the deck runs out go on to the next deck.
Pay 5 RT to draw an extra card.
Whenever you draw a disaster card reveal and play it immediately. Resolve the disaster and continue drawing. When Disaster cards are played, they are removed from the game.
Every player starts with a pick ability of 1. For every increase in pick ability (as a result of card play), you may, when drawing a card, draw an extra card, pick 1 of your choice and place the others back on the top of the deck. (Disasters don't count against your pick limit).


3. Implementation Phase

Play 1 card from your hand to the table.
Pay 5 ET to play an extra card.


4. Progress Phase

Max hand size is 4 cards. Discard excess cards. (If a card is discarded it goes to the bottom of its deck).


The game ends when the Apotheosis of Technology card (in the 30th century deck) is revealed. The player with the most Victory Tokens at the end of the game wins.

name: Battle Nations Outpost
description:
A deck building card game based on the Battle Nations Video Game. Each player controls their own outpost.

Each player gets his own small Imperial Basic Deck. All cards in this deck have 2 basic Traits: Build and Fight. Build is used to recruit units, characters, and buildings. Fight is used to defeat threats. Besides the Build and Fight Traits, cards also have additional abilities including: Draw, Store, Replace, Heal or Repair, Gain VP, and modifiers that increase their traits or the traits of other cards.

Players also share three Common Decks:
Threat Deck (Missions and Invasions)
Building Deck
Unit Deck (Units and Characters)

- Each player shuffles their Basic Deck and draws 5 cards.
- Shuffle the 3 common decks. All decks are face-down.
- Place the top 4 cards of the Threat Deck face-up in a line in the middle of the table. These 4 cards are known as the Threat Spread. There must always be 4 cards in the Threat Spread.
- Similarly make spreads for the Building and Unit Decks.
- As play proceeds each player will have a modified Basic Deck, a hand of 5 cards, their discard pile, a victory pile (defeated Threats), and a storage pile.

Players take turns with each turn comprising two phases:

1. Action Phase
- Play cards from your hand (played cards are put in your discard).
- Use Build points to recruit buildings, units, and characters from the Building and Unit Spreads. The cost of a card in build points is its Recruitment Cost (RC). When a card is recruited, place it in your discard pile.
- Use Fight points to defeat threats from the Threat Spread. The cost to defeat a threat in fight points is its Threat Value (TV). Place defeated Threats into your victory pile.
- At the end of the phase discard all un-played cards from your hand.

2. Draw Phase
- Draw 6 cards from your deck to form your hand for next turn.
- If you have no cards left in your deck, shuffle your discard and draw from it.

Victory tokens are earned by playing certain cards. Place VT into your Victory Pile along with defeated Threat cards.

The game ends at the end of the turn any common deck is used up.
Add up your VT (Victory Tokens) plus the TV (Threat Value) of all Threat cards in your victory pile, deck, hand, and discards.

The player with the most victory points wins.

name: Blade Runner
description:
A card game for 2-4 players based on the cult classic science fiction movie Blade Runner.

There are 4 available Blade Runners (Deckard, Bryant, Holden, Gaff) with each player starting as one of them. Each operative has a unique special ability.

Players share a common deck which has seven types of cards, each of which has a special ability and a rank:
Replicant Take top card of discard
Location Draw 3 cards and keep 1
Test Look at opponents hand
Combat Opponent must discard 1 random card
Transport Draw 2 cards
Investigation Look at next 7 cards in deck
Complications Steal 1 random card from opponent

Players take turns with each turn comprising four phases:

1. Search Phase
- Draw 2 Cards.

2. Action Phase
- You may play 1 card for its special ability.

3. Assignment Phase
- Complete an Assignment - discard at least 1 of each card type.
- Threat Rule: An assignment play must contain 1 or 2 combat cards with a combined rank value that is equal to or greater than that of the rank value of the Replicant.
- Search Rule: The combined ranks of the Investigation and Test cards played must be equal to or greater than 10.
- Travel Rule: The ranks of the Location and Travel cards must be within 2 of each other.

4. Debriefing Phase
- Max hand size is 8 cards. Discard excess cards.

The first player to complete 3 assignments is the winner.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Bourgeoisie
description:
A card game for 2-4+ players. A game of social advancement in 17th century France in which players, by means of the purchase of ennobling offices, advance their bourgeoisie families into the aristocracy.

Each player builds up 1 family at a time. Once a family has been ennobled and has an income of 30+ silver per turn from investments, it is retired and the player must start a new family.

Players share a common deck comprising card types: Families, Trade, Bonds, Land, Offices, and Events. The Land, Bond, and Office types are collectively called Investments. Most cards have a value and may also have special characteristics.

The opportunity track has a place for the deck and 10 cards to be laid out:
Discard | 01 | 02 | 03 | 04 | 05 | 06 | 07 | 08 | 09 | 10 | Deck
A card’s position on the track is the cost in opportunity tokens to take it.

There are 4 different types of Common Markers: silver coins, gold coins upgrade markers and opportunity tokens

Each player starts with 1 random family card in play and with 1D10 Silver.
10 cards are laid randomly to each of the 10 spaces on the opportunity Track.

Players take turns with each turn divided into 9 phases:
1. Family Phase
- If you have no family card in play you may put one in play from your hand at no cost. You may have a max of 1 non-retired family card in play at a time. Cards in play are placed face up in front of you.
- You may put a trade card in play for gold equal to its value. You may not put a trade card into play if you don’t have a family card in play.

2. Revenue Phase
- Gain Silver equal to the combined value of every card you have in play for your most current family.

3. Fate Phase
- Gain 1D6 Opportunity Tokens (OT). OT can be saved from turn to turn.

4. Opportunity Phase
- You may buy cards on the Opportunity Track using your OT. Place these cards into your hand. A card’s position on the track is the cost in OT to take it. Some Event cards are resolved as soon as you buy them.

5. Capital Phase
- You may discard one or more cards from your hand. Gain silver equal to the value of the discarded cards.

6. Conversion Phase
- Convert silver to gold. Every 10 silver converts into 1 gold. Keep the change.

7. Investment Phase
- If you have a trade card in play with your current family, you may buy Land and/or Bond cards from your hand. These cost gold equal to their value. A family may have multiple Land and Bond cards in play.
- If your current family has at least one Land in play, you may buy an Office card for gold equal to its value. A family may not have more office cards in play than land cards.

8. Noblement Phase
- If your current family has at least 1 office and is making 30+ Silver per turn, it may retire.
- If it is making 50+ Silver per turn, you must retire it, even if it has no office.
- Set the retired Family aside in its own stack.
- When retiring, you must discard all your gold.
- Next turn you may start a new family.

9. End Phase
- Max hand size is 7 cards. Discard excess cards.
- If there is a card in the 1 spot on the Opportunity track discard it. Then slide all the remaining cards down from 10 to 1 filling in all empty spaces on the Track. Flip over cards from the deck to fill in empty spots (starting with the 10)

The game ends when a turn ends and there are no cards left in the deck.

Score Prestige Points (PP) for each of your families. A family gets PP equal to the value of its Lands and Offices. If a retired family has no Offices it gets -5 PP. Get an extra +5 PP for each retired family you have after the first.

The player with the most Prestige Points at the end of the game wins.
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: Colonizers
description:
A space colonisation game for 2-5 players in which players attempt to establish high scoring colonies before their opponents.

Players share a common deck formed of seven different cards types: Planets, Ships, Extractors, Protection, Distance, Events and Growth.

Planet cards have 2 attributes: hazards and resources. There are 8 types of hazard and 8 types of resource.
There are 4 types of ship cards, representing 4 propulsion types and 4 corresponding levels of speed. Certain ships cannot be used with certain distance Cards.
There are 4 types of Extractor card. Each type of extractor can successfully extract 2 types of resource. Additionally, each Extractor card has a secondary trait of colonist. There are 6 types of colonists each worth a different amount of points in settlement scoring.
Each hazard has a specific type of protection card required to overcome it. Each protection card has a secondary trait of control. There are three types of control each worth a different number of points in settlement scoring.
Each distance card lists a distance value from 7 to 30. Each distance card also has an obstruction attribute. There are five types of obstruction. Each obstruction type may prevent the use of one specific ship type.
Event cards have a wide range of game altering effects such as increasing or decreasing trip times; stealing or destroying colonies; stealing, gaining, or losing cards; stealing, gaining, or losing VP.
Growth cards are added to a player’s existing colony. A single colony can have a maximum of one growth card attached.


To start each player is dealt 5 cards.

Players take turns with each turn comprising eight phases:

1. Draw Phase

Each player draws 1 card from the top of the deck and puts it in their hands.


2. Trade Phase

Players may trade cards from their hands. They may also trade ownership of missions and colonies.


3. Event Phase

The current player may play 1 event card or 1 growth card from his hand. Discard event cards once they are played.


4. Travel Phase

The current player places travel markers on his missions.
A mission with solar sails adds 1 travel marker.
A mission with gravity repulsors adds 2 travel markers.
A mission with a ram scoop adds 3 travel markers.
A mission with an antimatter drive adds 4 travel markers.



5. Launch Phase

The current player may launch a mission. A mission consists of 5 cards: 1 planet card, 1 ship card, 1 extractor card, 1 protection card, 1 distance card. All cards in a Mission must be compatible with each other, for instance, the protection card must be specific to the hazard type of the planet card. The stack of mission cards are placed face-up and staggered so as to be visible to all players


6. Settlement Phase

A Mission that has accumulated travel markers equal to or greater than the distance value listed on the mission’s distance card has arrived at its destination planet and set up a functioning, established colony.
The player in control of the mission colony immediately scores a number of VP = the value of the resource type plus the value of the colonists type plus the value of the control type.
Represent the conversion of the mission into a colony by discarding the distance and ship cards and the travel markers. Keep the Planet, extractor, and protection cards stacked face up in front of you.


7. Scoring Phase

The current Player gains 1 VP for each colony he has in play.


8. End Phase

Current player max hand size = 8 cards. Discard excess cards.


The game ends as soon as ten colonies are in play. Check for each of the 8 resource types. The player with the most colonies of a type gains an extra 3 VP. The player with the most Victory Points (VP) at the end of the game wins.

name: Cow Clicker The Card Game
description:
A card game for 2-4+ players based on the Cow Click social network game.

Players share two common decks: The Basic Cow Deck and The Premium Cow Deck. Each cow is worth a certain amount of mooney as listed on its card. Mooney levels are low in the basic deck and higher in the premium deck. Optional event cards can be added to the basic deck which take effect as soon as they are revealed and then immediately discarded.

To set up, 7 starting cards are separated from the premium deck and laid out face-up in “the stockyard” - the middle of the playing area.
The basic and premium cards are shuffled separately into two decks.
When shuffling the premium deck, 10 cards including the Cowmageddon card are shuffled separately and set to one side. This is known as the Cowntdown deck and comes into play towards the end of the game when the remainder of the premium deck runs out.

Each player draws 3 cards from the basic cow deck and puts them in their “pasture” (the area directly in front of them)

Players take turns with each turn comprising five phases:

1. Sale Phase
- You may discard a basic cow. The most basic cows you can have in your pasture is 5.

2. Buy Phase
- If you have 4 or less basic cows in your pasture, you may draw the top card of the basic deck and add it to your pasture. You may only add 1 basic cow to your pasture this way per turn.

3. Upgrade Phase
- You may discard 2 or more cows (basic and/or premium) to gain a premium cow, from the stockyard, with a mooney value exactly equal to the total mooney value of the cows you discarded. For Example: There is a 17 Mooney cow available as one of the 7 stockyard cows. You have in your pasture a 5 mooney cow, a 2 mooney cow, and a 10 mooney cow. (5 + 2 + 10 = 17). You discard them to get the 17 mooney cow and put it in your pasture.

4. Stockyard Phase
- If there are less than 7 stockyard cows available, flip over the top cards of the Premium deck until there are 7. If one of these is the Cowmageddon card the game ends.

5. Out to Pasture Phase
- Take the highest Mooney cow from the Stockyard and place it on the bottom of the Premium deck. If you are into the Cowntdown deck, skip this phase.

Players may trade (or Gift) Cows at any time. Trades (but not gifts) must be acceptable to both parties. The most basic cows you can have in your pasture is 5 and you cannot gift or trade someone basic cows if it would cause them to exceed their limit. You can have any number of premium cows.

The Game ends when the Cowmageddon Card is revealed. Your score is equal to the total Mooney value of all your cows divided by the number of cows in your pasture. (get the calculators...)
The player with the highest score at the end of the game wins.

name: David and Goliath
description:
A board game for 2 players with a Biblical Theme. One player is David, the other is Goliath. The aim of the game is to smite your foe.

The game area is a regular 8 X 8 grid. There are 2 rock tokens and 2 tree tokens placed randomly on the board. Figures are used to represent David and Goliath and start on opposite back rows of the board. Figures cannot move into or through rock tokens, but they can sling or throw through them. Figures cannot move or attack into or through Tree Tokens.

Players share a common deck. Some cards can be used by both players, others by David or Goliath, only. Cards allow players to move, attack or defend, or may be an event.

Each player draws a hand of 7 cards. Goliath gets 1 spear token. David gets 5 stone tokens.

Players take turns with each turn comprising 7 phases:


Draw Phase
Each player draws 1 card from the deck and adds it to their hand.

Event Phase
Each player may play one event card in this phase. Events are resolved immediately.

Goliath Move Phase
The Goliath player may move his figure on the board.
Discard a move card to move exactly the indicated number of spaces. Cards will indicate if the move can be orthogonal, diagonal, or both.
The David player may discard a negate card to end a move at any point during its progression.
Goliath cannot move into or through the space occupied by David.

David Move Phase
The David player may move his figure on the board (using the same rules as applied to Goliath)

Goliath Attack Phase
The Goliath player may make a spear attack or a sword attack. The Goliath player starts play in possession of a spear. As long as the Goliath player has his Spear he must make a Spear attack.
To make a sword attack discard a sword card to attack David if he is in an adjacent space. The card will indicate if the sword attack is orthogonal or diagonal. The sword attack will be one of three types: Thrust, Slash, or Chop. The David player may discard a defence card to block a sword attack. Some defence cards will not work against a certain type of sword attack. If a defence card is not successfully played, David is wounded.
To make a spear attack, the Goliath player must discard a sword card or a throw card. If a sword card is used, the attack is treated exactly like a thrust sword attack (even if the card says Slash or Cut). If a throw card is used the spear will hit exactly at the range indicated on the card.
Once thrown, if the Spear misses (a defence card is successfully played) place the spear token in the space occupied by David. Goliath is then without his spear. He can retrieve it simply by entering the space where it landed. If a defence card is not successfully played, David is wounded.

David Attack Phase
David may only make a Sling Stone Attack. To do so both a sling card, and a stone card must be discarded. The sling card determines the range. and can be used for orthogonal or diagonal attacks. The stone card is of 3 types: Fast, Curved, and Sinker.
The Goliath player may discard a defence card to block a sling attack. Some defence cards will not work against a certain type of sling attack. If a defence card is not successfully played, Goliath is wounded.
Once slung, if a stone misses (a defence card is successfully played) place a stone token in the space occupied by Goliath. David can retrieve it simply by entering the space where it landed.

End Phase
Max hand size is 7 cards. Discard excess cards.



Players share a common set of 4 wound tokens. For each wound your max hand size is decreased by one. Three wounds is death. The game end when one player kills the other.

name: Dark Crystal Quest
description:
A card game for 2-4 players based on the Dark Crystal movie.

Players share a common deck. Of these, 11 can be utilised to create a Crystal Combo (required to win the game), the others have special abilities which allow players to undertake a variety of actions (i.e. draw cards, steal cards, look at cards, switch hands …)

To start each player is dealt 3 cards. 12 cards are then spread facedown evenly over the play area – these are called Table cards and are available to be drawn (picked) by the players.

Players take turns, with each turn having 4 phases:

1. Fate Phase
- Take the top 2 cards of the deck and place them face down on the play area. If there are ever 12 or less Table cards available, draw and place extra cards face down until there are at least 12 Table cards.

2. Prophecy Phase
- You may play 1 card to use its special ability. When you play a card either discard it or return it face down to the table.

3. Quest Phase
- Draw 3 Table cards and put 2 of them in your hand. Return 1 of these cards to the Table.

4. Crystal Phase
- Reveal the Crystal Combo if you have it to win and end the game. The combo must contain 4 cards: one of each of the following 4 types:
I. The Gelfling or Jan or Kira card
II. The Crystal Shard or Dark Crystal card
III. The Castle of the Crystal or Sacred Chamber card
IV. The Grand Conjunction or Alignment of the Suns or Heal the Crystal card
The Prophecy card can be used as a wild card for any of the 4 types of cards needed in a combo.
- If not, max hand size is 5 cards. Return excess cards to the Table.

The first player to declare a Crystal Combo at the end of his turn wins the game.
categories: Card Game, Fantasy, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Demon Hunter
description:
A card and board game for 2-6 players in which each player takes the role of a Demon Hunter.

The game board depicts Europe in the late 1800s. 20 cities are marked on the board, with each city connected to 1-4 other nearby cities. Some cities may have an effect on die rolls or creature capabilities.

There are 3 decks:
- The Character Deck represents advantageous traits that the characters start the game with.
The Research Deck comprises cards aid that aid the Demon Hunters in their quest. Players acquire these during play. Card types include: Events, Spells, Weapons, Armour, Items, and Companions.
- The Creature Deck need to be small to fit easily on the map and represent the creatures that can be found in the various cities. Creatures have a strength and a victory point score (earned by defeating them)

Each player starts with 5 Hits. Each player draws and keeps 5 character cards. Each player rolls 1D20 to determine their starting City.
Randomly distribute the X top cards of the creature deck to random cities, where X = the number of players. (Max Monsters in any one city at start is 2)

Players take turns with each turn having 4 Phases:

1. Destiny Phase
- The current player draws the top research card from the deck and places it in his hand.

2. Evil Phase
- For each player roll 1D6: on a roll of 4+ flip over the top card of the creature deck and for each new creature roll 1D20. Place the creature on the indicated City.

3. Action Phase
- The Current player may take 2 actions. There are 6 possible actions:
1. Rest Action - Roll on a healing table to heal any hit points lost.
2. Travel Action – Roll on a movement table to move 0-2 spaces.
3. Search Action – Roll on a search table to determine whether you can find a creature to fight.
4. Recruit Action - Put one Weapon, Item, Armour, or Companion card into play. A character can only have a maximum of 1 armour card, 2 weapon cards and 2 companion cards in Play
5. Research Action - Roll on a research table and draw 0-3 research cards from the deck and put them in your hand. (You may do a max of 1 research action per turn)
6. Trade Action - If you are in the same city as 1 or more other Demon Hunters, you may trade resource cards, in hand or in play.

4. Fate Phase
- Max hand size is 7 cards. Discard excess.
- If at the end of a turn, any city has 5 or more creatures, it is
overrun and all players lose.

When fighting creatures roll 1D20 (The Battle Roll) and add any force bonuses you might have. If this number is equal to or greater than the strength of the creature you defeat it. Place defeated creatures in your victory pile.
If your modified roll was less, the creature remains in play and roll on the Wound Table taking damage accordingly. If you are reduced to zero Hits skip your next turn and return to play with just 1 hit.
If after losing a battle roll, you still have hits you may decide to either
continue the combat or flee. If you decide to continue, make another battle roll against the same creature. If you decide to flee, you may stay in the city or move 1 space.

The game ends at the end of the turn the creature deck has been exhausted. The player with the most Victory Points at the end of the game is the winner.

name: Doomed
description:
A card game based on the Doom Video Games for 2+ players.

Players share a common deck comprising 6 card types:
Action, Weapon, Equipment, Location, Zombie and Demon.
Action, Weapon and Equipment cards are collectively called Aid cards.
Zombie and Demon cards are collectively known as foes. All foes have damage and strength ratings. They may also have traits that will interact with other cards.

Counters are used to keep track of Life Points, Doom Points and Ammunition. Each player starts with 19 + 1D6 Life Points and 2D6 Doom Points.

The game is played over a series of turns with each turn comprising 6 phases.

1. Doom Phase
- Lay out 3X cards where X is the number of players. These are the doom cards.

2. Leader Phase
- Determine the leader for this phase. The player with the least life is the leader. If tied for least life, the player with the least Doom Points goes first.

3. Tactics Phase
- Starting with the Leader, and going clockwise, each player picks 1 of the doom cards laid out in Doom Phase. If it is an Aid card place it in front of yourself. If it is a Foe card place it in front of an opponent. If it is a Location card, place it in front of yourself or an opponent. If a player gets a Location card, he must discard any other location card he may already have in play.
- Continue going around until all doom cards are assigned.

4. Resolution Phase
- Start with the leader and go clockwise.
- Each location has a foe limit. The player discards foes in front of him in excess of the foe limit.
- Discard 1 or more ammo tokens, equipment, and action cards to defeat a foe with a strength equal to less than the force of the cards discarded.
- Gain Doom Points equal to the damage rating of defeated foes. Discard defeated foes.

5. Damage Phase
- Each foe in front of you does damage to you equal to its damage rating (damage received corresponds to an equal loss of life points)

6. End Phase
- At end of turn a player may have a max of 6 aid cards in front of him. Discard excess.
- If you did not take damage in damage phase, heal 2 life points.

The first player to gain 50+ Doom Points and to have killed at least 1 Boss is the winner. Lose all your life points and you are out of the game. If only one player remains, he wins.

name: Boxel
description:
Boxel is a fun packed family party game that brings color to your game nights!

Try to score points by placing your Boxel in the matrix before it gets switched or destroyed by the other players. Draw from the bag and use cards to get control over your luck.

A fast-paced abstract game that is easy to learn and fun to play. It only takes a few seconds to setup and around 30 minutes to play.

name: Assassins Creed Revolution
description:
A card game based on the Assassins Creed Video Game Series, specifically the third instalment.

Players share a common deck comprising 13 cards (numbered 1-13) in 8 suits (Assassin, Character, Enemy, Income, Location, Manoeuvre, Mission, Weapon).

Players take Turns with each turn comprising 4 phases


Draw Phase
Draw 2 cards.

Action Phase
Discard 1 card to trigger its special ability according to its suit.
Assassin = Draw 2 cards.
Character = Steal 1 random card from opponent.
Income = Look at opponent’s hand. Trade 1 card with him.
Enemy = Opponent must discard a random card.
Location = Discard your hand and draw 7 cards.
Mission = Look at next 7 cards in deck. Put one in your hand.
Manoeuvre = Search discard for 1 card and put it in your hand.
Weapon = Opponent (his choice) must give you a card or discard 2 cards.

Combo Phase
Make one or more combos. For each combo you make draw 1 card. There are 4 types of combos:
Flush (4 cards of the same suite)
Straight (4 or more cards of different suits forming a straight as in Poker)
Fighting Combo: 1 each of: Assassin, Enemy, Weapon, and Manoeuvre
Journey Combo: 1 each of: Location, Mission, Character, and Income

End Phase
Max hand is 9 cards. Discard excess cards.



The winner is the first player to make 7 card combos.

name: Green Arrow
description:
A card game based on the TV series Arrow.

The game starts with 2 decks: Arrow Deck (green cards) and Villain Deck (pink cards). As the game progresses, players will create their own personal hero decks composed of Arrow (green) cards they have previously played.

Each card has a power level. Green cards range from 1 to 4. Pink cards range from 1 to 7. Certain Green cards will also get extra power depending on their text. Each card will also have usually 2 or more traits: Criminal, Guns, Archer, Petty, Brawler, Drugs, Psycho, Police, Tech, Government, Organization, Money, Political, Skill, Equipment, Action, Arrow, Romance, Ally, Friendship, Family.

Each round has 6 phases, with players taking it turns to act first each round:

1. Foundry Phase
- At the beginning of each round flip over the top 3X cards from the Arrow Deck and place them face up in a row (Foundry Row). X = the number of players.

2. Starling Phase
- At the beginning of each round flip over the top 2X cards from the Villain Deck and place them face up in a row (Starling Row). When you flip over a minor card (power of 1 or 2) flip over another card and stack the minor card with it. The stack counts as a single card on the Starling Row, but has the combined power of all of the cards in the stack. (The stack may contain several minor cards under the major card (power 3 or higher)).

3. Hero Phase
- Starting with the round leader each player picks one card from the Foundry Row and puts it into their hand. This continues until each player has picked 3 cards. If you pick a card that says draw 1 immediately draw one card from the Arrow Deck and put it in your hand. If the drawn card also says draw 1 then draw again and so on. If the Arrow Deck is used up draw 3 cards from your Hero Deck instead. At the end of the phase the lead player passes to the player on his left.

4. Capture Phase
- Starting with the (new) lead player, each player captures one or more cards (or stacks of cards) from the Starling Row and puts them into their Victory Pile. The total power of the pink cards you capture must be equal to or exceeded by the total power of the green cards you picked/drew this turn.

5. Bonus Phase
- Put a victory token in your victory pile if you have played in capture phase 2 or more skill cards, 2 or more money cards, 2 characters with a romantic relationship or 2 characters with a family relationship

6. Recovery Phase
- Place all green cards you played this turn into your Hero Deck discard pile. Any Villain card not captured remains in play.

Each player has his own victory pile. During the course of the game players will acquire victory tokens and villain cards which they will keep in their victory pile.

The game ends when all the villain cards are captured. Players add up the value of all the cards and tokens in their Victory Pile. Each villain card is worth victory points equal to its power rating. 2 extra victory points are gained for each Super Villain captured. The player with the most victory points at the end of the game wins.
categories: Card Game, Fantasy, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Trump Card
description:
Description from the publisher:

Created for a time when the world needed laughter the most, Trump Card is Thymia Games' first release. Inspired by games such as Cards Against Humanity, Exploding Kittens, Munchkin and King's Cup, this game will make you want to make a YUGE wall and be great fun. Belive us! Trump Card is unlike any other board or card game not just because of how you play, but because of what it’s about. Most games have a rather neutral, light-hearted subject; pirates, zombies, rabbits, or a fantasy land far-far away. This is not one of those games. Be prepared to backstab and screw your friends over and over again, all for fun of course.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Humor, Negotiation, Party Game, Political, Print & Play
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Take That, Team-Based Game, Trick-taking

name: Glee Club Competition
description:
A card game for 2-4+ players themed around competing High School singing clubs. Each player represents the Glee Club of one school.

Players share a common deck comprising 4 card types: Songs, Singers, Events, Special.

The game is played over 4 semesters (one whole school year) representing 4 competition levels (Sectional, Regional, State and Nationals) and scoring 2, 4, 6 and 8 competition points respectively.

Each semester has 6 phases:

1. Audition Phase
- Each player is dealt a hand 10 cards.

2. Rehearsals Phase
- Players made discard up to 4 cards and draw replacements.

3. Changes Phase
- Players made discard up to 3 cards and draw replacements.

4. Final Set Phase
- Players made discard up to 2 cards and draw replacements.

5. Competition Phase
- Players make melds from their hands. A meld can contain a maximum of 4 singers, 3 (non-duplicate) songs, 2 events and 1 special card.
- Players score their melds. Score one point for each card in your meld. Score additional points if your singers give bonuses to the songs in your meld. Score additional points if your events give bonuses to the singers in your meld.
- The player with the highest scoring meld also wins that quarters competition and gets to add those competition points to their Glee total.

6. Break Phase
- Players discard their melds and the remaining cards in their hands.

The player with the highest Glee point total at the end of the year is the winner.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Gods of Magic
description:
A card, dice and storytelling game for 2-6+ players. Each player takes the role of one of the Gods of Magic. The Gods create magical realms and fill them with all manner of strangeness. The God whose realms are the most complete and fantastical becomes the current Chief amongst them.

Players share a common Deck. There are 5 suits of 40 cards each: Location, Action, Entities, Descriptors and Objects. Each card has a victory point value between 1 and 10.

Each player has his own domain - a player’s part of the table where he keeps his realms. A realm is a group of cards that must include one location card and are placed face up in a separate group within your domain. A complete realm contains at least one card of each of the 5 suits.

To start each player is dealt a hand of 10 cards. Each player may play up to 3 cards to their domain to make 1 or more realms.

Players take turns with each turn comprising 3 Phases:

1. Draw Phase
- Draw 1 card and place it in your hand. Max hand size is 10 cards. Discard excess cards at the end of this phase.

2. Play Phase
- Play one card from your hand to add to one of your Realms or to create a new realm. If creating a new realm, the card played must be a location card.

3. Dice Phase
- Roll the D10 and consult the Magic Table. The die result will have an effect such as discarding cards, drawing extra card, playing an extra turn, etc.

The realms and what happens to them tell stories. In the spirit of the game players are expected to say something about a realm when they modify it, thus describing the whims and actions of the Gods of Magic. This is usually a statement listing all the cards within the realm and how they interact with each other. This may include elements not listed on the cards themselves. If any description fails to meet the playing groups standards, the play may be stopped by the other player and the offending player must make a different action.

The winner is the first player to score 200 or more victory points. If 2 or more players score 200+ at the same time, the player with the higher score wins.
categories: Card Game, Dice, Fantasy, Print & Play

name: 幸せな時間 (Shiawase na Jikan)
description:
Publisher's summary
幸せな時間 (Shiawase na Jikan) in English is 'Time of Happiness'. This is game #2 in the Ars Combinatoria system.

Each player has a deck of six cards which are "Good thing in your past", "Very good thing in your past", "Good thing in your present", "Very good thing in your present", "Good thing in your future", and "Very good thing in your future".

Players are given a theme, think about their past that relates to the theme, and chooses "Good" or "Very good" thing in the past card according to what they have thought. Do the same for their present and future.

During the game, your opponents asks several questions about what you thought, then guesses the cards you chose. Opponents win the game if they guessed your cards correctly.

Any number of players can play this game as long as there are enough decks of cards.

各自6枚のカードを持ちます。
カードには「過去のいいこと」「過去のとてもいいこと」
「現在のいいこと」「現在のとてもいいこと」
「未来のいいこと」「未来のとてもいいこと」と書かれています。
回答者が、過去・現在・未来の3つのタームでどちらのカードを選んだか
他の人はそれを当てることができれば勝ちです。
勝敗よりも会話を楽しむためのゲームです。
カードがあれば何人でも同時にプレイできます。
categories: Card Game, Educational, Party Game, Word Game

name: Alaska
description:
A card and dice game for 2-5 players. Each player controls 1 town in Alaska and develops his town in order to score the most points.

Players share a common deck comprising resource (investment) cards and event cards. The deck comes in three parts. All the “early” cards are shuffled to make the top third of the decks. All the “late” cards are shuffled to make the bottom third of the deck.

There are 13 resource card types: Indians, Mines, Fish, Wood, Ships, Ground, Air, Government, Military, Oil, Agriculture, Service, and Tourism. Resource cards have an associated cost, score and revenue value.

Each player starts with 2 dollars.

Players take turns with each turn comprising 2 phases:

1. Revenue Phase
- Gain 1 dollar for free.
- Roll 1D6 or 2D6. Gain revenue from every one of your resources whose score matches your roll.
- If your roll did not match any of your cards gain a second dollar for free.
- Dollars normally come from the Bank. If, however a resource is marked “ticket”, then 1 dollar comes from an opponent instead of the Bank.

2. Investment Phase
- The top 3 cards of the deck are turned face up.
- You may buy one card for its face value.
- You may buy a second card for double its cost.
- You may buy the third card for triple its cost.
- You may buy a fourth card for quadruple the cost and so on.
- Cards not bought are set aside and can be bought later by any player on their turn in addition to and/or instead of the top 3 that are always revealed.
- If the card is an event card it affects the player who draws them. Event cards, once drawn and played, are removed from the game. If an event card allows a free buy, it must be of a card set aside or drawn this turn; if there are no candidates, it has no effect.

The game ends when there are no more cards left to draw. All players in order may ten spend the last of their dollars. Scoring is undertaken as follows:
- Score 1 VP for every card you own.
- Score 2 VP for every Government and Military Card.
- Score 3 VP for every Oil and Tourism Card.
- Score 2 VP if you have the most cards of a type (check all 13 types)
The player with the most VP at the end of the game wins.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: X-Com Skirmish
description:
An abstract skirmish level squad combat board & card game for 2 players, based on the X-Com video games. One player plays X-Com units, the other the Aliens.

Use a large hex-map as the playing area. Every hex has 2 ratings: terrain and elevation. These affect defence ratings and line of sight. Terrain is selected at the discretion of the players.

Players use figures, miniatures or chits to represent units. Each unit represents a single soldier or alien.
- X-Com units come in a variety of types: civilian, military, squaddie, specialist, officer, hero or SHIV robot. Each has a hit value between 1 and 4, cost between 1 and 4, and can, through card play, undertake actions from one or more tables according to their type.
- Alien units come in 15 different types. Each has a hit value between 1 and 5, a cost between 1 and 5 and can, through card play, undertake actions from a table that is unique to their type

Players share a common action deck. Cards are of a number of type: Move, Attack, Defence or Special.

Players take turns with each turn comprising 3 Phases:

1. Tactical Phase
- Draw 5 cards (or 4 if you only have 2 units left or 3 if you only have 1 unit left)

2. Move and Fire Phase
- Your units may individually move and fire in either order as you decide. All of your units get one free move of 1 hex. In addition to the free move, you can play one move card on one unit (per turn) to move it again a number of spaces as stated on the card. Normally only one unit is allowed per space. Exceptions include units being carried such as a soldier carrying a wounded comrade or a captured alien or flying units passing over or hovering over other units
- Play an attack card to have a unit attack. The attack card has a number which is the range of the attack. All attacks do a base of 1 hit of damage. A unit reduced to 0 hits is killed.
- Your opponent may play defence cards to negate damage. A defence effect negates a base of 1 hit of damage.

3. End Phase
- Max hand size = 5 cards (4 if you only have 2 units, or 3 if you only have one unit left). Discard excess cards.

The winner of the game is the first to achieve complete destruction of all opposing units.

name: Death by Shakespeare
description:
A game for 2-4 players about the modes of death and character types in the plays of Shakespeare.

There are two decks of cards:
- Character Deck. These represent the characters within the play. Each character card has a special ability which are generally activated by die rolls.
- Death Deck. These represents the methods by which characters die within the play. Each death card has a rating of 1 to 6.

To start roll 1D6 +3. This will give a random number between 4 and 9. This is the number of characters who will die before the play is over.

Each player is dealt 5 random character cards. These are kept face up on the table in front of the player.

Players take turns with each turn having 3 acts:

1. First Act:
- Draw 2 death cards. You max hand size is 5 cards. Discard excess cards.

2. Second Act:
- Place 1 death card on an opponent’s character card. A character may have any number of death cards stacked on him.

3. Third Act:
- Roll 1D6. This is the Death Die. If the rolled number matches the number on any death card on an opposing character, then the character is killed. If there are multiple characters that can be killed, pick just one. A killed character and any death cards on it are discarded.
- The death roll will often activate the special abilities of one or more characters. The attacked player may respond first with the reaction of one of his characters. Play of reactions of other characters proceeds in a clockwise direction.

The game ends when the pre-determined number of deaths is reached. The winner is the player having the most living characters left at the end of the game.

name: My Name Is Tarzan
description:
A card game for 2-4+ players with a Tarzan theme. The game involves playing cards to complete the storyline for an adventure involving Tarzan. The form of the adventure is described as a Tarzantra and has the form:

My name is Tarzan, (Title)
I have great (Attribute)
And am skilled at (Ability)
I like to wrestle (Animal)
Me and my friend (Ally)
Journeyed to (Locale)
Where with (Object)
We executed a daring (Action)
And defeated the (Foe)

Players share a common deck. The deck has 9 suits of 9 cards each: Title, Attribute, Ability, Animal, Ally, Locale, Object, Action, and Foe. Players are dealt 5 cards each at the start of the game with the remaining cards being spread out face down in the middle of the table.

In a sing-song fashion the leader says the first line of the Tarzantra. The first player to his left gets to play a Title card from his hand if he has one. If he does, then he keeps the card face up in front of him in his personal victory pile and he draws a face down card and puts it into his hand. (He must also say the name of the card to complete the line of the poem)

If he does not have a Title card, he must look at one face down card on the table. He may keep it, or leave it and put a different face down card into his hand. If he had to draw a card, the next player to his left gets a chance to play a Title card to complete the line. This continues until someone plays a Title card.

Once someone does, the leader speaks the second line of the Tarzantra. The player who played the Title card gets the first chance to finish the second line with an Attribute card. This continues line by line, until the full Tarzantra is completed.

When the Tarzantra is complete, the player to the leader’s right becomes the new leader and starts a new Tarzantra.

The game ends when 5 Tarzantras have been completed (or 3 for a short game, or 7 for a long game). The player with the most cards in their victory pile at game end wins.
categories: Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Wizard Chess
description:
An advanced version of Warlord Chess, designed by Cyborg Centaur Games, Wizard Chess adds the element of a classic deck of cards. Like Warlord Chess, it is a new set of rules for playing chess for two players, using a chess set.

Players place pawns to act as Farmers, trying to form patterns which are used to recruit higher value pawns; but Bishops now act as Mages, and allow you to draw cards in your Hand of Magic. You can use the various combinations of cards like two pairs, three pairs etc. to cast mighty spells that alter the battlefield, adding a new depth to the rules of Warlord Chess.

—description from the publisher

name: Fantasy Microcosm
description:
A card game for 2-4 players with a Fantasy theme.

Players share a common deck of 60 cards of 5 card types: Character, Holding, Group, Event and Thing. Some event cards are designated as Spells. Cards have a points value between 1 and 4 and 1 of 2 types of abilities (cards used in combination with each other or cards that have a special ability). Abilities activate as soon as the card is played.

Each player starts with 2 cards and then take turns to draw 1 card from the deck and play 1 card from their hand. When a card is played it is placed face up on the table in front of the player. If the card has a non-combo ability (e.g. discard 1 group, steal character, draw 1 card etc.) this gets used immediately. All the cards in front of you are known as your Fief.

When the last card is drawn the discard is shuffled and cards drawn from it (cards only ever go into the discard pile when another card sends them there). When there is no deck or discard left, players continue taking turns, playing one card at a time from their hands until all cards are played. At this point scoring is undertaken.

Cards score their basic points value but if they are combo cards may score extra points if the player holds the right combination of cards. The final scores are based on all the cards in your Fief and the combos they make. The winner is the player with the most points at the end of the game.

name: Biohazard War
description:
A 2-player card game based on the Resident Evil franchise using collectible card game style mechanics. One player is the Heroes. The other is the Umbrella Corporation.

There are 2 decks:

The Hero Deck has 3 types of cards: Teams, Characters and Events. These have the following sub-types: Operative, Merc, Survivor
The Umbrella Deck has 3 types of cards: Facilities, Units and Events. Unit cards are further divided into the following sub-types: Soldiers, Monsters, Zombies and Vehicles. Traps are a subtype of Event.


Event cards and Traps, when played, take effect immediately and are then discarded. Other types of cards remain in play.

The Umbrella player starts with all 6 Facility cards in play except for the New Facility.
The Hero searches his deck for 1 Team Card and puts it into play.
Each player draws 2 cards for their starting Hand.

Each turn has 6 phases:


Draw Phase
Each player draws 2 cards from their respective decks.
If the Hero player has no teams in play, he must search his deck for a team, put it in play, and then shuffle his deck.

Event Phase
Certain event cards are played only in this Phase. Players take turns, starting with the Umbrella player.

Recruit Phase
Cards are put into play from the players hand. When putting a card into play it is placed face up on the table.
The Hero player puts team cards into play. The Hero player then puts character cards into play. Character cards must be attached to team cards. A team card may have up to 2 characters attached (or 3, if at least one of them is a survivor).
The Umbrella player may play one or more Units.
The Umbrella player may play the New Facility card.

Assault Phase
The Hero player may conduct one assault - one of his teams may attack one target facility. The Hero player commits the team, its characters, and any event cards he wants to play that will assist an assault. He adds up the force values and bonuses of all these cards and adds 2D6. This is the Assault Force Total (AFT).
The Umbrella player commits the targeted facility, one unit, one or more traps and any events that will assist in defending against the assault. He adds up the force values and bonuses of all these cards and adds 2D6. This is the Facility Defence Total (FDT).
If the AFT is equal to or greater than the FDT the base is destroyed and removed from play. If the FDT is greater the Team is destroyed and removed from play. Of the attached characters of a destroyed Team 50% are discarded and 50% put back in the Hero players hand.
If the facility is destroyed all other cards used in its defence are discarded. If the facility wins, there is a 50% chance the defending unit is still discarded. Win or lose all Event and Trap cards are discarded.

Search Phase
The Umbrella player may conduct one Search and Destroy Mission - one of his Units may attack one target team. This is handled just like an assault. The Umbrella player generates a Search and Destroy Force Total (SDFT). The Hero player generates a Team Defence Total (TDT). An Umbrella unit, even if it wins, has a 50% chance after combat of being discarded.

End Phase
Max hand size is 5 cards. Players discard excess cards.
