The Hero Player wins if all the Umbrella facilities are destroyed. The Umbrella Player wins if all the teams are destroyed.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: The Librarians
description:
Card game for 2-4+ players based on The Librarians TV show. The aim of the game is to make and score melds.

Players share a common deck comprising 8 types of cards: Librarians, Foes, Relics, Aids, Places, Situations, Knowledge and Mysteries, Some cards can be combined with others to score extra points.

Players are dealt 3 cards with players taking turns to play. Each turn has 4 phases:


Draw Phase
Draw 2 Cards.

Action Phase
Reveal 1 card to perform an action:
Librarians = Draw 1 Card
Foes = Opponent must shuffle 1 card of his choice back into the deck. Then he draws 1 Card
Relics = Gain 1 Meld Point
Aids = Look at next 4 cards in deck. Replace this card with 1 of those.
Places = Draw 1 random card from the discard and keep it.
Situations = Give this card to opponent. He must give you a different card in return.
Knowledges = Look at an opponent’s hand
Mysteries = Draw 2 cards. Shuffle 2 cards from your hand into the deck.

Or reveal 3+ cards of the same type to perform an action and/or score points:
3 Librarians = Draw 2 cards
3 Foes = Opponent must shuffle 1 card of his choice back into the deck.
3 Relics = Gain 2 meld points
3 Aids = Look at next 4 cards in deck. Keep 1 of them.
3 Places = Draw 3 random cards from the discard. Keep 1 of them.
3 Situations = Steal 1 random card from an opponent’s hand
3 Knowledges = Look at an opponent’s hand. Take 1 card. Opponent draws 2 cards
3 Mysteries = Draw 3 cards. Shuffle 3 cards from your hand into the deck.
4 Different Librarians = 4 meld Points. Shuffle these into deck and draw 4 cards
Gangs All Here: 5 Different Librarians = 5 meld points. Shuffle these into deck and draw 5 cards
Round the World: 5 Places = 5 meld points. Shuffle these into deck and draw 5 cards
The Library: 5 Relics = 5 meld points. Shuffle these into deck and draw 5 cards
Conclave of Villains: 5 Foes = 5 meld points. Shuffle these into deck and draw 5 cards
Combined Genius: 5 Aids = 5 meld Points. Shuffle these into deck and draw 5 cards
It’s Complicated: 5 Situations = 5 meld Points. Shuffle these into deck and draw 5 cards
Know it All’s: 5 Knowledges = 5 meld points. Shuffle these into deck and draw 5 cards
It’s a Mystery! = 5 Mysteries = 5 meld points. Shuffle these into deck and draw 5 cards


Meld Phase
Players may declare a meld. A meld must have 1 of each of the 8 card types and scores 10 points. For every combo a meld has it scores 1 extra point. After scoring all melded cards are discarded and the hand filled to 7 cards.

End Phase
Max hand size is 8 cards. Place excess cards back on top of the deck in any order.



The game ends when 10 melds have been completed. When this happens all players may have one last chance to make a meld. The player with the most meld points is the winner.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Global Inequiality
description:
A poker style card game for 2 players. The premise of the game is that the rich get richer and the poor get poorer and that the gap between the rich and the poor has been increasing for decades. Each hand represents 10 years starting with the 1950s. One player is the Rich. The other player is the Poor.

Players share a common deck of 7 card types of 8 cards each. Three of these (Rent Seeking, Tax Evasion and Extraction) can be used by the Rich player; three others (Enlightened, Investment and Reaction) can be used by the Poor player. The 7th suit (Neutral) can be used by both players.

During a turn 5 cards are dealt to each player. Each player may discard up to 3 cards and draw replacements. Players then reveal their hands and score them. Each player will have cards they can and cannot use and score points as follows.

Hand: Notes: Points:
1 Pair 2 of the same suit 2
3 of a Kind 3 of the same suit 4
4 of a Kind 4 of the same suit 6
5 of a Kind 5 of the same suit 8
2 Pairs 2 pairs from different suits 5
Full House 1 pair and 1 3 of a kind 7
Flush 4 from 4 different suits 5

At the end of 7 hands, the player with the most points wins. If the rich player wins, it is business as usual. If the poor player wins, then the world is a better place.

name: DKT Salzkammergut: Das kaufmännische Talent
description:
A variant of the popular DKT game, which is a monopoly variant. Players roll dice to move on a board and visit locations in the Salzkammergut in Österreich. Most of the locations are for sale, the moving player can buy them. If a player's pawn later enters an already owned location, the player must pay rent to the owner. When owning all locations of a site (two to four locations per site), the owner can build houses and later hotels on the locations to increase the rent for other players. The game ends after a fixed time, or if all players but one are bankrupt.

This version includes some major differences to the standard DKT game:

In every region there are two souvenirs, priced 50 and 100. You can buy one of them when you stop in the region, the cheaper one is sold first. You can only own one souvenir per region. Whenever you pass start, you get 50 extra for each souvenir you own.

Field 21 is a Gebäude ("building") special field. It allows you to build up to 2 houses or 1 hotel (if you already have 4 houses) on each property you own, even if you do not own the whole region.

There are no auction rules, only the person stopping on an unowned property can buy it.

You can sell properties among players at all times for whatever prices you settle on.

The rulebook includes a long section describing the various tourist attractions depicted in each region.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Trading

name: FusionPlay Heroes
description:
FusionPlay – Heroes is the first mobile NFC card game. It’s played with physical cards, each containing a Near Field Communication chip. These chips enable communication between the playing cards and a smartphone. As soon as you slide a card under the smartphone, it appears on the screen of the phone. Then the app processes the actions and visualizes the results. The game itself is a duel between two players like a digital-analog homage to beat-em-up games of the 16-bit era. Each player chooses one of the 4 heroes and uses the heroes’ unique skills to win the battle. The game is fast paced and always motivates to play “just one more round”. All components are pocket sized, so the player can always have them with them.

Before starting the game, the smartphone tray plates need to be placed on the table, and the smartphone should be placed on top of the tray plates. These little bars make it easy to slide the cards under the smartphone. Both players choose one hero and take all 7 cards of this hero. The app is launched, and a “Single Round” or a full match is selected. Then both players scan their hero cards in the “Choose your Heroes” screen.
The game begins.

Both players shall choose one card, and slide it (with the face down) under the smartphone. The players will take their cards back again. The app will uncover both played cards, then process and visualize the effects of the cards. Depending on the actions taken, the players will deal damage, heal themselves, buff themselves, lower the stats of the opponent, or debuff; e.g. inflict negative conditions like burning or bleeding. Attacks can also miss or hit critically, which depends mainly upon the Dexterity values of the heroes. The game ends, when one player runs out of lives. When playing a “best of 3”, you need to win two rounds for winning the whole match.

Many effects from the actions depend on one or more attributes of the heroes. An example: Donar’s “Into the Skies” raises the Dexterity for one round. His “Hammer Throw” adds twice the Dexerity to the damage. It may seem like a good move to raise dexterity first, and use the “Hammer Throw“ one round later. A good, but also very predictable move. Each hero has 6 unique actions that all trigger different effects. Most of them trigger multiple effects at once. If you remember beat-em-up games from the good old 16-bit era, then imagine every card symbolizes one button on the controller, triggering a specific move.

Besides using your actions in the right situations, they can also be used to sum up to powerful combos. Each hero has two unique combos and one mighty super-combo. To trigger a combo, you need to play the cards in a specific order and then activate them by playing the hero card itself. The hero card can also be used to block an opponent’s combo, or to pause one round, and regenerate some energy.

--description from the publisher
mechanics: Hand Management, Simultaneous Action Selection, Take That

name: eXistenZial
description:
A card game for 2+ players based on the movie eXistenZ.

Players share a common deck comprising 8 card types which have differing effects when played:

Person - When you play a person card place it face up on the table in front of you. You control that person. It stays in play until killed. Person cards count for scoring.
Kill - Play a Kill card to cause a target Person to be discarded. Main Characters cannot be killed until there are no cards left in the deck, and then only one may be killed, not both.
Control - Play a Control card to take control of a target Person.
Location - Play a Location card to discard the previous location and replace it with this one. Location cards count for scoring.
Mechanism – Play a Mechanism card to produce the effect it describes.
Gamepod - When you play a game pod card place it face up on the table in front of you. You control that game pod. It stays in play until it gets diseased. Game Pod cards count for scoring. The player with the most Game pod cards may play 1 additional card per turn.
Disease – Play a Disease card to cause a target Game Pod to be discarded.
Quote - All players score their cards in play:
1 Point for playing the Quote Card
1 Point for each Person
2 Points for each Main Character
2 Points for the Location
1 Point for each Game Pod



The Allegra Geller and Ted Pikul cards are placed face-up in the centre of the table. These are the Main Character cards are not controlled by any player to start, but any player may play a control card to take control of one of them. Each player is dealt 3 cards.

Players take turns. On a player’s turn, he draws 1 card from the deck and puts it in his hand. Then he may play 1 card from his hand. Max hand size is 7 cards. Extra cards are shuffled back into the deck.

The game ends when there are no cards left in the deck, and all players have played all the cards from their hands. After the last card has been played all players score one last additional time. The player with the highest score wins.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Arcane Armies
description:
A common deck card game for 2-4+ players with a fantasy army-building conquest theme.
Players share a common deck. There are 2 basic card types: Units and Spells.
Units are further divided into Individuals and Groups. All cards have a strength value between 0 and 10 and a special ability that is activated and resolved as soon as the card is played.

The deck is shuffled and placed face down in the centre of the table. The top card is flipped over to be the start of the discard pile. The first player to go is dealt 2 cards.
The second player to go is dealt 3 cards. The third player to go is dealt 4 cards and so on.

Players then take turns with each turn being divided into 4 phases:


Conquest Phase
You win if, at the beginning of your turn, your cards in play have a combined strength of 40 or more.

Scour Phase
Draw 1 card from the deck and put it in your hand.

Deploy Phase
Play 1 card from your hand face up to the table. Immediately resolve the card’s special ability. If the card has a strength of zero (most spells) it is immediately discarded. Otherwise it stays in play as part of your army, its strength contributing to your army’s total strength. You may play a second card if the strength of both cards played is 10 or less.

Last Phase
You may unflip a card in play by discarding a card from your hand. Max hand size is 5 cards. Discard excess cards.



A player wins if, at the beginning of your turn, your cards in play have a combined strength of 40 or more.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Open Drafting

name: Wealth Manager
description:
A card game for 2-4+ players in which players try to increase their net worth and earning potential.

Players share 2 common decks. Players begin with the starting deck and then move onto the expert deck. There are 9 Card types: Acumen, Real Estate, Business Investment, Debt Management, Personal Expenses, Business Expenses, Stock Portfolio, Collectible Items and Windfall.

Each player starts the game with:
Job Income: 8K per month
Total Expenses: 6K per month
Savings: 15K
Stock Market Portfolio: 15K
Assets: Home = 300K and Cars = 30K
Retirement Funds = 200K
Liabilities: Mortgage = 250K and Cars = 20K

Players take turns (representing 1 month) with each turn comprising 5 phases:

1. Payday
- Earn money from all of your income streams including job, businesses, and rentals.

2. Expenses
- Pay for all your expenses. This includes mortgage payments, car payments, living expenses, loan payments, and real estate overhead.

3. Opportunity
- Draw 1 card from the current deck. The card drawn will present either an opportunity you may take, or an extra expense you must take depending on the card.

4. Market
- This phase represents volatility in the markets. Players roll on the asset adjustment table once for each of their assets to see if value or income is affected.

5. End
- Discard all cards. Calculate your Net Worth.

The game ends when players have gone through both decks. The player with the highest net worth is the winner. If tied, the player with the highest monthly income is the winner. If still tied, the player with the most liquid cash wins.
mechanics: Commodity Speculation, Hand Management, Open Drafting

name: Titanic Card Game
description:
A series of card games for 2-4 players employing a Titanic theme and a metagame scoring system.

Players share a traditional 52 card deck. Alternatively, a homemade deck can be used with the following suites: Lifeboats, Crew, Passengers, Iceberg

Each player starts with 10 Legacy Points (LP) and plays 7 phases (7 hands of traditional card games) as follows:

1. DESIGN PHASE
- Play a hand of Poker. The worst hand is held responsible for the lack of Lifeboats and gets -1 LP.

2. COLLISION PHASE
- Play a game of Old Maid. The loser is held responsible for the collision and gets -2 LP.

3. LIFEBOAT PHASE
- Play a game of Fish. The winner gets the most people onto the Lifeboats and gets +3 LP.

4. HEROICS PHASE
- Play a game of Rummy. The winner reveals the most Heroic moments and gets +4 LP.

5. SINKING PHASE
- Play a game of Hearts. The loser experiences the most Horrific deaths and gets -5 LP.

6. LOCATION PHASE
- Play a hand of Black Jack. The best hand finds the wreck and gets +6 LP.

7. EXPLORATION PHASE
- Play a game of War. The winner is the first able to properly explore the Wreck and gets +7 LP.

At the end of the game the player with the most Legacy Points is the winner.

name: Terrible Tales
description:
A game of story telling for 2 or more players.

Players share a common deck of cards - each giving a location, character, theme, item or event. Each player draws 5 cards (or 7 for a longer game).

A player starts to tell a story. Players try to incorporate the idea on one of their cards into the story. If a player does this he may discard that card. After discarding, the player to his right continues the story, and so on.

The story ends when the last player discards his last card.

If a player manages to say something very witty, or clever, or profound, or poetic, or funny, or memorable, the other players may award him one or more story points.Players may deduct Story points for poor performances. A player may at any time deduct a story point to discard a card & draw a new one.

At the end of the story, the player with the most Story points wins.

name: Terminator Skirmish
description:
A 2-player skirmish Game with a Terminator theme. One player is Skynet (Robots). The other player is the Resistance (Humans).

Play is undertaken on an 8x8 grid representing a destroyed city. The board is populated with terrain at the discretion of the players. Terrain types include: wasteland (relatively clear), bone fields (demoralizing to humans), rubble (good hiding spots for humans), ruins (good hiding and cover) and massive debris (limiting movement and attack options)

Each side gets a set of units with differing movement abilities and strength (hits). Counters or chits are used to control movement around the board. Damage counters are used to keep track of the damage (hits lost) of the individual units.

Each player has his own unique deck of cards. Card types include: attack defence, movement and special. Cards may have limitations regarding which units they can be applied to.

Each player places his units in any of his last 3 rows. Units may not stack.

Players take turns with each turn comprising 3 Phases.

1. Supply Phase
- Draw 3 cards from your deck and place them in your hand.

2. Action Phase
- Play cards from your hand (no limit).
- Use move cards to move one of your units up to the indicated number of spaces. Your opponent may use certain special cards to negate a move.
- Use attack cards to have a unit attack a target unit at the exact range indicated by the card and do damage to the target as indicated by the damage rating of the attack card. Your opponent may use defence cards to reduce hits caused by an Attack.

3. End Phase
- Max hand size is 7 cards. Discard excess cards.

The winner is the player that destroys his opponent’s base first.
categories: Miniatures, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Print & Play
mechanics: Area Movement, Grid Movement, Open Drafting

name: Monopoly Junior: Shopkins
description:
Description from the publisher:

Welcome to Shopville, home to all shopkins. Spend a day in the life of Shopkins, hanging out in the fruit and veg aisle or chatting away in the pantry!

Collect as many characters as you can, and use Shopkins money to keep everyone on the go! Pick up shopville challeges and don’t forget to add your money to the Shopkins purse! Go around the board until you are out of money and try to avoid being sent to the frozen aisle!

Hang out with all your Shopkins bffs in this special edition of monopoly junior!
publishers: Hasbro, Winning Moves Australia Pty Ltd

name: Horcrux Hunters
description:
A card game for 2+ players based on the Harry Potter universe. Voldemort has created 7 horcruxes, each one containing a piece of his soul. In order to defeat him, you must destroy all his horcruxes first.
Players share a common deck comprising 4 types of cards: Horcrux, Action, Character and Special. Each player starts with 5 cards.

Players take turns with each turn comprising 4 Phases:


Destruction Phase
If you have a horcrux in play, you may play the cards needed to destroy it (each horcrux requires a specific combination of character, action or special cards to destroy it). The horcrux card then goes into your victory pile. The non-horcrux cards used do not produce their other effects.

Horcrux Phase
You may play a horcrux card from your hand. Place it on the table face-up in front of you. It is in your possession.

Action Phase
You may play up to 3 action, special or character cards from your hand for their special effect (e.g. draw extra cards, search deck, steal cards etc.)

Draw Phase
Fill your hand to 5 cards if it contains less than 5.
Max hand size is 7 cards. Discard excess cards.



The winner is the player that kills Voldemort after all 7 horcruxes have been destroyed. If you killed Voldemort but did not destroy the most horcruxes, you must share the victory with player who did.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Jurassic Park Rescue
description:
A board game for 2-4 + players based on the Jurassic Park universe. The aim of the game is to be the first team to find the kids and bring them back to the Visitor Centre
without first being killed off.

The board is an 8x8 grid in the form of a map of the island. In one corner is the Visitor Centre (safe start and end zone) from which the players’ teams start. In the opposite corner is the kids token. The map is populated with terrain in the form of 4 randomly placed lakes, 4 randomly placed mountains and 4 randomly placed valleys.

Six dinosaurs are placed randomly on the board (but not adjacent to the visitors centre). These dinosaurs are selected at random from a table of 6 dinosaur types. Each dinosaur type is immune from one of the tactics that might be employed by the players (e.g. you cannot outrun the Velociraptors).

Each player starts with an 8 member team. Players roll 8 times on a Team Table to get the composition of their team. The 6 different types of team member have skills that improve the tactical abilities of the team. Results and changes are recorded with paper and pencil. During the game, players will lose and gain team members.

Players share a Common Deck. The deck has 7 types of cards representing the tactics that can be employed to evade the dinosaurs: Hide, Run, Block, Trap, Shoot, Distract, and Special.

Players take turns with each turn comprising 4 phases.


Equip Phase
Draw 1 Card from the deck and add it to your hand. Max hand size is 5 cards.

Special Phase
Special cards not meant to be used in other phases may be played (discarded) for their effects in this phase.

Dinosaur Phase
Pick 1 Dinosaur by random and roll once on the random movement table to determine how it moves. Dinosaurs move orthogonally but not diagonally and must obey a set of movement rules related to terrain and the location of other dinosaurs.
If a dinosaur enters the same space as a team, the team will be attacked. The team must attempt to escape. An escape attempt must use 1 tactic from the 6 available (Shoot, Run, Hide, Trap, Block, and Distract. Next, the player must make an escape roll using 2 six-sided dice. Add up the total of the 2 dice rolls and add to this the number of teammates with the matching tactic. Next, play (discard) up to 2 tactics cards and add their bonuses. At least 1 of the tactics cards played must match the chosen tactic. If the Total (roll + team bonuses + card bonuses) is equal to or greater than 12, then the team escapes with no casualties. If the total is less, the team loses a number of random team members equal to the difference. If a team loses all its members, that player is out of the game.
After the attack, the team must retreat 1 space away. If you are attacked and you control the kids token you may lose control of the token.

Move Phase
Move your team pawn 1 space orthogonally. You may play (discard) 1 special card to move the team farther per the cards instructions. Terrain will affect where the teams move to and teams cannot enter spaces occupied by dinosaurs or other teams. If you enter the space containing the kids you take possession of it. The kids token moves along with your team pawn.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Grid Movement, Hand Management, Open Drafting

name: 10 MAXx
description:
Description from the publisher:

10 MAXx Game is Free to Print 66 cards and Play.
Play 10 rounds to create 10 words and try to obtain maximum points.
There are 120 to 130 possible points available after 10 maximum rounds.
10 MAXx takes word building beyond 15 letter word length to gain points, in fact with this game you can create almost any word from the dictionary.
How to play:

Deal 5 random cards to each player, after observing the cards the players can choose to exchange 1 of the 5 cards for a new card from the deck and if the new card is the same as the old card, it can be rejected by the player for another card. 1.1: The exchange of the card can be repeated at the start of each round.
Place the 10 cards marked level 1 to level 10 instruction cards faced down in a sequence at the centre of the playing area. 2.1: Start by turning the card marked level 1 face up to read the instruction to create a 3 or a 4 letter word for 3 or 4 points.
Using the letters from your own 5 cards plus the letters from the 5 cards dealt to the opposite player so therefore each player is using letters from 10 cards to create a word and to write down the word as an (Example) round 1: BUST = 4 points.
Each letter can be used twice from a single card because each letter is mirrored on the cards.
categories: Card Game, Educational, Math, Print & Play, Word Game

name: BBQ Slam
description:
Throw the dice and count the pips. Now you have to take your spatula and hit the card with this number as fast as possible! Did you get it? Then you win the card!
The first player to get 6 consecutive cards is the winner of the game.

name: Schweine Yatzy
description:
A game with 11 cards, one per round. Each round is drawn a card. On the card, you see which combinations of dices are necessary to win the card. The starting player throws the specified number of dice and has to place at least one dice before each new throw. If he has achieved a combination, he takes the card and marks the combination achieved. If another player in this round achieves the same or a higher combination, he can pick up the card and mark the matched combination. When the round is over, the winners of the finished round will start in the next round.
At the end, the winner is, who has the most points on his cards.

name: Racing to the North Pole
description:
A dice and board game for 2-4+ players themed on the race to the North Pole undertaken by various explorers in the early 1900s. Players move their pawn from the start space to the North Pole and back again.

Players choose from one of 6 pre-defined expeditions or use a random method to generate their own expedition. Each expedition has 9 stats: Men, Dogs, Food, Gear, Skill, Will, Ship, Time, and Hoax. These stats represent the composition, skills, supplies, start point, start time and legitimacy of the expedition – these may change during the course of the game.

The board is a track 30 spaces long including a start space at one end and the North Pole space at the other end. Players share a 50-card common travel deck which influences how far an expedition will move during a particular turn.

Players take turns with each turn has 3 Phases:

1. Event Phase
- Roll once on the event table. Except for the blizzard result, all other results will require the player to make a test against either Gear, Will, or Skill. A test is resolved by rolling 1D10. If the number rolled is equal to or less than the value of the stat, you pass the test. If it is less, you fail the test which will usually result in a permanent loss of a stat or a penalty to your move total in the travel phase.

2. Travel Phase
- Draw 5 travel cards. You may discard up to 2 cards and draw replacements.
Add up the move values of all 5 cards. This is your move total - move that many spaces forward. You must stop upon reaching the North Pole.
- If you land on an opponent’s pawn that is not on its starting space, move it back 1 space.
- If you have 2 or more dog cards move an extra +1.
- If you have 4 or more trek cards move an extra +1.

3. End Phase
- Consume 1 food point.
- If there is no food left then -1 dog.
- If there is no food or dogs roll on the casualty table and resolve. This will result in the loss of men, will or skill.

Play continues until all expeditions return to their start point, or fail in the process. Victory points (VP) are awarded as follows:
- 1 VP for reaching the North Pole.
- An extra 2 VP for being first to reach the North Pole.
- 1 VP for getting back (Surviving).
- 1 VP for being the first to get back.
- 1 VP for never failing a morale check.
The player with most VP wins.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Point to Point Movement

name: Gotland runt spelet
description:
User summary:

This offshore sailing game allows players to recreate various courses of the classic Baltic Sea regatta Round Gotland Race (Swedish: Gotland runt). Four courses are suggested although it's easy enough to set up custom or other historical courses.

Yachts race across a square grid according to wind strength and direction which are changed periodically as indicated by a spinner: strength by rolling a die, direction by player choice.

Certain spinner results occasion the drawing of event cards from one of two decks depending on whether a yacht has a headwind or a tailwind. These cards may speed a yacht up or slow it down, cause it to drift, or even knock it out of the race (although the rules suggest that the storm cards can be removed).

name: ESPN SportsCentury Timeline Card Game
description: Your goal is to get rid of your cards by playing them in the correct chronological order in a timeline. Play cards featuring sport facts/events from football, baseball, basketball, hockey, boxing, tennis, golf and international sports. The first player to play all their cards wins.

name: James Bond 007: Special Mission
description:
Players take the role of 00 agents, competing against each other through a set of different Bond-movie based missions, trying to win the title of 'James Bond 007'

This is a game for 2 - 6 players. Each player chooses a mission. The aim is to score points either by completing a mission or collecting weapons, gadgets and cars. The first player to get 4000 points wins.

On each mission, players may take the following actions: move, engage in conflict, request help from Q. Players may come into conflict with counter agents (played by other players, as needed). Outcomes are determined by dice rolls.

Players score as the go on evaluation sheets which are provided as part of the game. Players also can take on the roles of M and Q. M administers the game play and adjudicates. Q is in charge of supplying cars, gadgets and weapons.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Spies/Secret Agents

name: Mortal Kombat Arena
description:
A 2 player card game based on the world of Mortal Kombat. It simulates a tournament match between 2 characters.

Each player chooses one character (from a choice of 20) at the beginning of the game. Each character starts with 20 hits. Each character has 2 special abilities and a unique list of fighting techniques. Each technique has a name, a cost, and an effect. The cost is in the number and type of cards that must be played to produce the effect which will be either offensive or defensive in nature. Offensive techniques, or attacks, will cause damage reducing the opposing character by 1 Hit. A defence will reduce the damage of an attack by an indicated amount. Some techniques produce an Auto-Kill effect. If one is produced and your opponent is unable to reduce or negate it, you automatically win the match.

Players share a common deck of 52 cards: 10 x Punch cards, 10 x Kick cards, 10 x Grab cards, 10 x Athletic cards, 6 x Focus cards, 4 x Link cards and 2 x Warrior cards. Players start with a hand of 7 cards.

Players take turns comprising 4 phases:

1. First Refresh Phase
- Fill your hand to max hand size (or less if stunned)

2. Attack Phase
- Play (discard) cards to make an attack. If you play a combo effect, you can make an extra attack. Your opponent may play cards to produce defensive effects, fully or
partially negating one or more of your attacks.

3. Tactical Phase
- You may discard any unwanted cards in your hand.

4. Second Refresh Phase
- Fill your hand to max hand size. (or less if stunned)

The winner is the player who reduces the opposing fighter to zero or less hits or gets an Auto Kill effect.

name: Street Fighter Arena
description:
A 2 player card game based on the world of Street Fighter. It simulates a match between 2 characters.

Each player chooses one character (from a choice of 17) at the beginning of the game. Each character starts with 20 hits. Each character has 2 special abilities and a unique list of fighting techniques. Each technique has a name, a cost, and an effect. The cost is in the number and type of cards that must be played to produce the effect which will be either offensive, defensive or otherwise in nature. Offensive techniques, or attacks, will cause damage reducing the opposing character by 1 hit. A defence will reduce the damage of an attack by an indicated amount.

Players share a common deck of 52 cards: 10 x Punch cards, 10 x Kick cards, 10 x Grab cards, 10 x Athletic cards, 6 x Focus cards, 4 x Link cards and 2 x Warrior cards. Players start with a maximum hand of 7 cards (though this may reduce during the course of the game).

Players take turns comprising 4 phases:

1. First Refresh Phase
- Fill your hand to max hand size (or less if stunned)

2. Attack Phase
- Play (discard) cards to make an attack. If you play a combo effect, you can make an extra attack. Your opponent may play cards to produce defensive effects, fully or
partially negating one or more of your attacks.

3. Tactical Phase
- You may discard any unwanted cards in your hand.

4. Second Refresh Phase
- Fill your hand to max hand size (or less if stunned)

The winner is the player who reduces the opposing fighter to zero or less hits.

name: Justice League Unlimited Adventures
description:
A card game for 2-4+ players set in the Justice League universe.

Players share a common deck comprising cards of 4 different types: Primary Heroes, Minor Heroes, Villains and Complications

The board is a circular track of 24 spaces with each space containing instructions to draw, steal, play or discard cards.

Players start with a hand of 3 cards and then take turns to play as follows:
- First draw 1 card from the top of the deck and add it to your hand.
- Roll 1 six sided die, and move your pawn that many spaces clockwise on the track. Resolve as follows:
• If you land on an opponent’s pawn, steal 1 card from his hand and add it to your own.
• If you land on a space that instructs you to play a card, place a card of the indicated type on the table face up in front of you. These are your mission cards.
If you don’t have the indicated card type, draw a card instead. If you already have 2 cards of that type out (or 1 of a villain) do nothing.
• If the space instructs you to discard a card, target an opponent’s mission card of that type. If there are none, target your own. If you have none, do nothing.
• If the space instructs you to steal a card, move an opponent’s mission card of that type over to your mission cards unless you already have enough, in which case do nothing.
• Other board space results are self-explanatory

A mission is a hand of 7 cards that contains 2 Primary Heroes, 2 Minor Heroes, 1 Villain and 2 Complications.

The winner is the first player to complete 3 missions.
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: Féetoibelle
description: 4 pretty fairies are invited to the grand ball at the castle. But before dashing off in a coach to dance beneath the stars, everyone has to get back her crown, her necklace, her fan and her handbag. A board and memory game where you have to find you own accessories and be the first one to arrive at the castle.

name: Dance School Competition
description:
A card drafting game for 2-4 players in two parts. In the first part the players build up their dance schools. In the second part the schools participate in competitions.

There are 3 Decks. The build deck is only used in the first part of the game. The Judging and Competition decks are used in the second part of the game.

Build Phase:

The build deck card types include: Students, Teachers, Classes, Numbers, and Modifier cards. Cards have a score in one or more traits, or will give other cards a bonus to their score in one or more traits. Traits include: Base, Beginning, Intermediate, Advanced, Jazz, Tap, Ballet, Contemporary, Modern, Lyrical, Musical Theatre, Hip Hop, Solo, Duet, Form, and Heart. All traits are assigned a score.

The top 12 cards of the build deck are laid out face up. Players take turns picking 1 card at a time until all 12 cards are picked. This constitutes a round. A short game will have 3 rounds, a medium game 4, and a long game 5 rounds. After the first round, the first player to pick goes to the player who was the last to pick in the previous round. Picked build cards are placed face up in front of their owner in a grid format and remain in play for the rest of the game.

Build cards are placed next to each other in a grid like matrix. Side by side (orthogonal) cards and cards whose corners are touching (diagonal) are considered to be adjacent. Many cards will give point bonuses to adjacent cards:

Teachers give bonuses to all adjacent students.
Students give bonuses to adjacent numbers if their style matches, so for example: If it is a jazz number, the number will get jazz bonuses equal to the jazz bonuses of any adjacent students.
Some cards give bonuses to all cards of a particular type even if not adjacent.


Competition Phase:


Before a competition, each player may switch the places of 2 cards within his grid.
First shuffle the Judging deck and draw 5 cards. These are placed face up in the middle of the table. Each judging card lists a trait that the judges are emphasizing.


All scores in these traits are doubled for all players in this competition.

Next, shuffle the Competition Deck. Each player draws 4 cards and places them face up in front of them. Competition cards will modify a player’s base score.
Each player adds up the total value of all of his cards including build cards, current competition cards and current Judging cards.
The player with the highest total score wins that competition. At the end of the competition discard all judging and competition cards. Repeat as necessary dependent on game length (1 round for short game, 3 for medium, 5 for long).


The winner is the play with the highest overall score after the appropriate number if rounds.

name: Tales of the Borrowers
description:
A card game based on the Borrowers, the tiny people that live hidden in our houses and borrow only what they need.

Players share a common deck comprising 10 cards of each of 7 card types: Places, Threats, Escapes, Friends, Foods, Objects, and Tools. Players start with a hand of 7 cards.

Players take turns with each turn comprising 3 phases:

1. Draw Phase
- Draw Cards from the deck to fill your hand to 7 cards.

2. Action Phase
- You may discard 1 card for its effect:
• Places = Discard 1 more card and draw 2 cards
• Threats = Opponent discards 1 random card from hand
• Escapes = Steal 1 random card from an opponent’s hand
• Friends = Give this card to opponent and draw 2 cards
• Foods = Draw 1 card
• Objects = Put any card from the discard into your hand
• Tools = Discard hand and draw 7 new cards

3. Meld Phase
- You may make a meld of 7 cards of one of the following 10 types:
• Borrower’s Feast: 3 Friends + 4 Foods
• Dangerous Journey: 3 Places + 2 Escape + 2 Threats
• Monty Haul: 3 Objects + 2 Tools + 2 Foods
• Friendly Visit: 2 Friends + 3 Places + 2 Escapes
• Great Adventure: 1 of each Type
• Tricks of the Trade: 3 Tools + 4 Escapes
• Home and Hearth: 4 Objects + 3 Foods
• Full House: 4 Friends + 3 Objects
• A Big Scary World: 4 Threats + 3 Places
• Weapons of Choice: 4 Tools + 3 Threats
- You cannot make a meld of a type already made this game.
- If you complete a meld discard your hand and draw 7 new cards.
- If you don’t have a meld, you must discard your hand down to 6 cards.

The winner is the first player to complete 3 melds.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Cards of Might and Magic
description:
A card game for 2+ players based on the video game Heroes of Might & Magic III.

Players compete in 3 categories: Might, Magic and Gold. Most cards increase your score in one of these 3 categories. At the end of the game, the player with the highest score in the most categories is the winner.

There are seven Decks:
• Hero Deck - Heroes are of 2 types: Might Heroes and Magic Heroes. Each Hero also belongs to 1 of the 8 town types. Each player starts with 1 randomly drawn Hero.
• Build Deck - These are building located in towns within your Kingdom. Some indicate affiliation with 1 of the 8 town types. Your kingdom may contain multiple Town Affiliations.
• Explore Deck - Locations, Structures, and items found within your Kingdom, but outside of your towns.
• Creature Deck - Each creature belongs to 1 of the 8 town types.
• Spell Deck - Spells belong to 1 of 4 types: Air, Earth, Fire, and Water.
• Skill Deck - Advanced Knowledge known to your Heroes.
• Artefact Deck - Magical Objects of great Power.
Cards may have attributes as follows: Ranged, Defence, Quick, Burst, Incapacitate, Reinforce, Buff

All cards owned and controlled by a player are placed face up on the table in front of them. This is each player’s Kingdom.

Players take turns with each turn comprising 4 Phases:
1. Build Phase - Draw 1 Card from the Build Deck and add it to your Kingdom.
2. Creature Phase - Draw 1 Card from the Creature Deck and add it to your Kingdom.
3. Recruit Phase - Roll once on the recruit table and draw 1 card from the Hero, Skill, Spell or Artefact deck, dependant on the die roll.
4. Explore Phase - Draw 1 Card from the Explore Deck and add it to your Kingdom.

The game ends when every player has completed 7 turns.

The player with the most Ranged cards gets Might +5 and Magic +5.
The player with the most Defence cards gets Might +5 and Magic +5.
The player with the most Quick cards gets Might +5 and Magic +5.
The player with the most Incapacitate cards gets Might +5 and Magic +5.
The player with the most Burst cards gets Might +5 and Magic +5.
The player with the most Reinforce cards gets Might +5 and Magic +5.
The player with the most Buff cards gets Might +5 and Magic +5.

At the end of the game, the player with the highest score in the most categories (Might, Magic and Gold) is the winner.

name: Altun Ha
description:
A card bidding and building game for 2-4+ players themed around the Belize Mayan ruins of Altun Ha, occupied and built up between 200 BC and 900 AD before it was abandoned, probably due to a combination of overpopulation, drought, famine, social unrest, and civil war.

The players share a common deck comprising three types of cards: Bid Cards (also used for building), Trade Cards and Maya God Cards (wild cards). Each player starts with a hand of 5 cards.

The calendar token is used to keep track of turn order within a round. It is assigned randomly at the start of the game.

Each Round is divided into 8 Phases:
1. Calendar Phase - the player with the calendar token passes it to the player to his right.
2. Population Phase - the population level increases by 1 (it starts at level 2).
3. Draw Phase - each player is dealt 2 cards from the deck.
4. Trade Phase - staring with the player with the calendar token, each player may play one trade card from his hand. Trade cards allow players to draw extra cards, look at opponent’s hands, cause opponents to lose scoring points etc.
5. Bid Phase - all players must bid zero to two bid cards from their hands. Bidding is simultaneous with players revealing their bid cards at the same time. The player with the highest value bid wins the bid and becomes the Priest King.
6. Farm Phase - the Priest King must discard 1 or 2 Bid cards with a combined value equalling or exceeding the current population level. If unable to do so, the game ends immediately and the current Priest King loses 13 scoring points.
7. Build Phase - The Priest King may play up to 2 bid cards as build cards. A card of value 1 is placed by itself face-up in the middle of the table and is considered the first stage of a new temple. Higher level bid cards can be added onto already existing temples. They are placed staggered on the top of a temple with a level 1 less than the card being placed. (i.e. a level 2 card is placed on top of a level 1 card; or a level 6 card is placed on top of a level 5 card). The Priest King gains scoring points equal to the value of the cards he places. If unable to build, he loses 7 scoring points.
8. Cycle Phase – maximum hand is 5 cards - players discard excess cards.

The game ends immediately in any turn in which the Priest King is unable to feed his people in Farm Phase. The player with the most scoring points at the end of the game wins.

name: Cruise Ship Quest
description:
A board game for 2-4+ players with a Cruise Line management theme.

The map contains 18 regions. Each region directly connects to 1-5 other regions by course lines. Within each region are 3-5 cities which are connected to each other.

Players share a common deck comprising 5 types of cards: Destination Cards, Room Cards, Mess Cards, Crew Member Cards and Souvenir Cards. The Room cards are further divided into 3 types: Food Cards, Sleep Cards and Play Cards. Players start with a hand of 7 cards.

Players take turns with each turn comprising 7 Phases:

Itinerary Phase
- Draw 1 card from the deck and put it in your hand.

Investment Phase
- You may reduce your Cruise Point score by 1 to draw an extra card.
- You may then reduce your Cruise Point score by another 2 to draw a second extra card. (total 3 points)
- You may then reduce your Cruise Point score by another 3 to draw a third extra card. (total 6 points)

Business Phase
- Players may trade cards and Cruise Points with each other.

Launch Phase
- You may launch a new cruise ship. To do this you must play 7 cards from your hands. 6 cards must be Room cards (2 Sleep cards, 2 Play cards, 2 Food cards)
The seventh card is a city card; the location where the ship will start from.
- Start a Ship Log for the new ship and select a ship token. On the log record the identity number of the ship token and, ownership of the ship, its home port (starting location) and its value (based on the total value of the room cards played (each room has a value of 1 or 2)
- Discard all 7 cards at the end of the phase a ship is launched.

Sail Phase
- You may move each of your ships on the map. Each of your ships may move once on your turn in this phase. Ships move 4 ways:
• Region to adjacent Region (as allowed on the Region connectivity list)
• Region to City within that Region.
• City to Region that city is in.
• City to city within a Region (all cities within a region are connected)

Destination Phase
- If you have one of your ships at a city, you may play a matching Destination card.
For example: Your ship is at Cuba on the Map and you play the Cuba card. You score Cruise Points for arriving at a destination - gain 2D6 Cruise Points and add the value of your ship to get the base number of cruise points earned.
- Next, each other player may play one or more Mess cards from their hands against you. You may play crew member cards from your hand to negate Mess cards on a one to one basis. For each Mess card not negated, you earn 1 less Cruise Point.
- You may play 1 or more Souvenir cards. Gain 1 Cruise Point for each such card played.
- Record on the Ships Log the destination (City) you arrived at and the number of Cruise points you scored.
- Discard all cards played.

Port Phase
- Max hand size is 7 cards. Discard excess cards.

The game ends when players have gone through the deck 3 times and a turn starts and there are no cards left to draw. Scoring is then conducted.

The Ship that visits the most Cities gets 25 Cruise Points.
The Ship that visits the most Regions gets 25 Cruise Points.
A Ship that visits a city no other ship has visited gets 10 Cruise Points for each such city.
When a ship visits all the cities in a single region, this is called a Hat Trick. A Ship gets 10 Cruise Points for every Hat Trick it Makes.

The player with the most Cruise Points at the end of the game wins.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Hand Management, Open Drafting

name: Futbolmesa
description:
In this football simulation, two players use tactics, strategy, and luck in order to compete to score goals.
The match is developed in a square grid, in which the 22 players move and shoot according to their own statistics. The ball is placed at the intersections of the grid. Penalty kicks, goalkeeper movement, tactical fouls, combined attacks, head kicks, etc., are some of the possibilities.

name: Twelve Labors of Hercules
description:
A card game for 2-4 players themed around the adventures of the demigod Hercules. Each player tries to complete the most labours and adventures.

The board is a circular track divided into 12 spaces representing 12 countries or locations visited by Hercules. Each space has a specific set of instructions such as draw 1 card or take the top card of discard, draw two cards, next turn roll 2 dice to move and pick 1 etc.

There are 3 common decks of cards:

The Labours deck has 12 cards representing the 12 labours of Hercules. Each has 3 to 6 requirements needed to complete it. The deck is constructed so that the easier labours come into play before the more difficult ones. Only four labours are revealed at a time – every time a labour is completed the next card in the deck is flipped over as a replacement.
The Adventure deck is similar to the Labours deck but easier. Each adventure only needs 1 or 2 requirements to complete it. The Adventure deck is kept face-up.
The Hero Deck - each card provides 1 or 2 of the requirements needed to complete labours and adventures.


Players start with 2 hero cards and take turns with each turn comprising 4 Phases:

Move Phase

Roll 1D6 and move that many spaces in either direction. If you land on an opposing player steal 1 random Hero card from his hand and skip the action and labour phases.


Action Phase

If you did not land on another player, follow the instructions on the board space you entered. If you land on the Mediterranean you may complete the top face up Adventure card by discarding Hero cards with the necessary requirements. If completed, place the Adventure card in your Victory Pile.


Labour Phase

You may complete a revealed labour by discarding Hero cards with the


necessary requirements. When completed place the labour card in your Victory Pile.
Each Labour can only be completed if your pawn is in a specific space on the track (e.g. the Lion of Nemea can only be conducted in Greece, the Wild Mares of Diomedes in Thrace, the Golden Apples of Hesperides in Africa etc…)

Once one player has completed a Labour it is finished and is no longer available to other players to complete.


End Phase

Max hand size is 7 cards. Discard excess cards.


The game ends when all 12 labours have been completed. The player with the most labour points, gained by completing labours and adventures, wins.
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Bushido: Kano
description:
Description from the publisher:

Any who oppose the Savage Wave quickly come to realise just how terrible and fearsome an enemy an Oni makes. It turns out their youth are just as fierce, standing as tall as a fully grown man they take up the fight of the Savage Wave readily and with a lust for battle only possible from a member of this demonic race.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bushido: Boba
description:
Description from the publisher:

Another young Oni joins the ranks of the Savage Wave. Boba is a wicked shot, picking enemies off at will. When he channels his Ki he can lob his heavy iron shots with disconcerting accuracy. Those that have felt themselves safely out of his range are only proved wrong once.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Reilu Kimble
description:
A card game version of Kimble (aka Trouble). Promotional product for Reilu -bread brand. Comes with 55 cards and rules.

Players compete to have two of their color pawn -cards make a round around four slots in the table, one slot in front of every player. Pawncards move by playing movecards, and usually they make other players pawncards move also. If other player's pawncard is in front of you, you can play a card that "eats" the pawn, sending it back to it owners hand.

name: HeroClix ID Card
description:
From publisher's comprehensive rulebook:
Heroclix ID cards show that a character on your force has a special contact within a larger organization that may be able to
temporarily help. Many, but not all ID cards say they are “Unique”, and therefore only one ID card with that set symbol and collector number can be added to your force. When adding an ID card to your starting force, you must also add an associated ID character to your Sideline. [ID cards have a cost of 5.]

Here is the text of ID cards:
Inspiration: “A specific effect that varies from ID card to ID card.”
Setup – At the beginning of the game, choose a character on your sideline with a name or real name matching this ID Card and turn it to a starting line. This character is called an ID Character. You can’t have more ID characters on your force than you have characters placed on the map at the beginning of the game. (If the card is Unique, it will say so here.)
Call in Help – At the beginning of your turn, you may activate one ID Card per force. To activate an ID Card, choose a friendly character that has no action tokens and is equal to or more points than the ID Character's starting line. Give the chosen character a power action, place the ID Character adjacent to it, and then remove this ID Card from the game and your opponent scores it. The ID characters can’t be carried, given double power actions, replaced, or assigned resources. The ID character returns to your sideline immediately: (a) at the beginning of your next turn, (b) if it's not within 5 squares of the chosen character, or (c) if it is removed from the map by another game effect.
Inspire – When a character friendly to an ID Character is in an adjacent square, they can use that ID Character's Inspiration.
categories: Collectible Components, Comic Book / Strip, Fighting, Miniatures

name: Starting Up
description:
Starting Up is a game about entrepreneurship. Players will start a company to design and market a brand new product. They will have to take loans and partners and decide when to pay them off. They will test the markets with prototypes and develop their own skills on their way to have the hottest new product in the market.

Every turn is divided in the following phases:

Investors Phase: Players roll the dice to see how many new investors they can get. There are multiple types of investors like the Angel Investor, the Partner or a Bank Loan. They will get you money and boost your product but you can´t win the game util you pay them off.
Market Phase: Improvement cards will be auctioned to the players. This will cost you money, but will improve your product.
Balance Phase: In this phase, you can choose to test the market with you product. If you decided to do so, You´ll roll dice dependening on your product stats to earn money if you can roll above your costs. Investors will also take their share of your earning.


A new turn starts after the current one is over util someone has enough money to pay off all investors that he/she has previously acquired.

—description from the designer

name: Roll Play: Erotic Story Dice
description: Roll Play Dice works like Rorys Story cubes. You select a number of Dice, roll them and either tell an erotic story with them or act out what you rolled. That is totally your decision!
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Pattern Recognition, Storytelling

name: X-Statix
description:
A card game for 2-3 players in which each player recruits a team of mutants for hire that use their powers and savvy marketing to achieve celebrity status and all the glory and riches they can get.

Players share a common deck comprising cards of four types: Heroes, Marketing, Missions and Powers. Players share a common set of money tokens (MT) and fame tokens (FT)

Players take turns with each turn comprising 7 Phases:


Opportunity Phase: Draw 1 card and put it in your hand. You may draw extra cards, but first for each you must pay 1D6 MT or pass. If you pass, you may draw no more cards.
Recruitment Phase: You may put mutants (heroes) from your hand into play. To recruit a mutant you must first pay 1D6 MT. If you choose not to, recruitment phase ends. When you recruit a mutant, place his/her card face up in front of you and place 1 FT on it.
Publicity Phase: You may attach marketing cards to your heroes. To attach a marketing card you must first pay 1D6 MT. If you choose not to the publicity phase ends. A mutant may not have more marketing cards attached than he or she has FT.
Mission Phase: You may play 1 mission card from your hand. To go on the mission, you must have at least 1D6 heroes. If you do not, skip the rest of this phase. Roll 1D6. This is the Carnage roll. For each point of carnage, discard one power card from your hand. For each point of carnage not negated by a power card, kill off 1 random Hero of your Team. Gain 1D6 MT for each killed hero. If you have any surviving heroes roll 1D6. Add the number of survivors. This is the success roll. If the success roll is higher than the carnage roll, the mission is a success and you gain 2D6 MT. You may discard power cards to add 1 to the success roll for each card discarded. All tokens and cards attached to a killed hero are discarded/lost with him.
Fame Phase: Each of your Heroes that survived a mission last phase gains a FT.
Fortune Phase: Gain 1 MT for each FT and marketing card you have in play.
End Phase: Max hand size is 5 cards. Discard excess cards.


The game ends when a player goes to start his turn, and there are no cards left in the deck. The player with the most MT at the end of the game wins.
categories: Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Fantasy

name: Zone Stalker
description:
A card game for 2-4+ players based on the Novella “Roadside Picnic” by the Strugatsky brothers. Each player is a Stalker, venturing into the dangerous Visitation Zones to bring back valuable artefacts left by visiting Aliens.

There are 3 Decks:
- The Stalker Deck. This deck is composed of cards the Stalkers use to avoid
Hazards and find Artefacts. Each card has a Rating in 2 Traits: Avoidance Rating (used to avoid hazards) and Detection Rating (used to find artefacts)
- The Zone Deck. This deck has 4 card types: Location, Hazard, Artefact and Events.
- The Character Deck. These represent Stalkers. Each one has a special Ability.

Players take turns with each turn having four phases:

1. Stalker Phase
The current Stalker fills his hand to 10 stalker cards drawn from the top of the stalker deck.

2. Zone Phase
A player may decide to completely skip the Zone Phase on his turn.
The current stalker flips over the top card of the Zone Deck and places it face-up in the middle of the table. This card is called the Primary Zone Card.
- If the Primary Zone card is a location the Stalker must discard a stalker card of his choice from his hand along with the location card.
- If the Primary Zone card is a hazard the Stalker must play (discard) a stalker card to avoid it. The Hazard card will have a danger rating. The Stalker must roll 1D10 and add the avoidance rating on the Stalker card he played to the roll. If this total is equal to or greater than the danger rating of the Hazard card he successfully avoids it. If the total is less, he must roll 1D10 on the Hazard Table. Either way discard the hazard card.
- If the Primary Zone card is an Artefact the Stalker must play (discard) a Stalker card to find it. The Stalker must roll 1D10 and add the detection rating on the Stalker card he played to the roll. If this total is 7 or greater he successfully finds it. The stalker places it face-down next to him in his Swag pile. If the total is less, he does not find it; discard the Artefact card.
- If the Primary Zone card is an Event card, resolve it and discard it.
- The Stalker may repeat this process as long as he still has Stalker cards in his hand.

3. Recovery Phase
If the Stalker skipped the Zone Phase completely, he may remove one injury marker. If he has 1 or more bracelets in his swag remove 1 additional injury marker.

4. End Phase
The player may discard none, some, or all of his Stalker cards. Players may trade Stalker and Swag cards.

The game ends when only 1 player is left alive or a new turn starts and there are no cards left in the Zone Deck. The winner is the last Stalker left alive or the one with the most Swag Points at the end of the game.

name: The Postman
description:
A board game based on the 1997 Science Fiction movie The Postman. One player is the Postmen. The other player is the Holnists.

The map shows about 40 owns linked by roads and includes other features such as rivers, forests, and mountains. The distance between two adjacent towns linked by a road is called a space. Towns have a rating of either small, medium, or large (which affects recruit rolls).

There are a variety of different types of units each of which have four differing statistics:

Move - the maximum number of spaces the unit can move in a turn.
Fight - when rolling the D6 to attack, a roll of this number or higher will kill an enemy unit in the same town.
Sneak – a unit may attempt to move through a stack of enemy units. To do this, it must roll this number or higher on a D6. This stat is also used to retreat from an enemy that enters a unit’s location.
Recruit - when rolling the D6 to recruit, a roll of this number or higher will convert a militia in the town into one of the player’s unit types.


A regular 52 card deck is used. The Postmen can use red cards. The Holnists can use black cards. Cards are played to influence dice rolls and statistics or to generate special events.

Players take turns with the The Postmen going first. Each turn is divided up into five phases:


Move Phase
Units can move a number of spaces up to their move stat rating and may attempt to move through a stack of enemy units by rolling their sneak number or higher on a D6.

Fight Phase
If opposing units are in the same town, they will fight. All units get to make one attack and all attacks are simultaneous.

Recruit Phase
Each unit may make 1 recruit roll if it occupies a town with 1 or more militia in order to convert 1 militia in the town into one of its unit types.

Militia Phase
If a town is unoccupied by Postman or Holnist Units roll 1D6 to see whether a militia unit appears.

Mail Phase
Draw 2 cards. Max hand size is 7 cards. Discard excess cards.



The aim of the game is to destroy the opposing Leader Unit.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction
mechanics: Open Drafting, Point to Point Movement

name: Unstable
description:
Enter Horsetropolis, a future where no humans remain and an aristocratic overclass of psychic horses rule. These merciless overlords send their mind-controlled horse minions to feed, breed, and conquer - until only one Stable remains!

This game was designed live at the Penny Arcade Expo (PAX) Australia 2017, during the "Let's Make a Board Game - Live!" panel. 'Unstable' (also 'Foal Play' and various other equestrian puns) was created on audience suggestions (horses, unstable relationships, mind control, area control, 'Animal Farm') and then condensed into a tabletop board game to be added to the PAX Aus Tabletop Library (and in print-and-play through BGG).

In Unstable, a game for 2-4 players, players split into two teams. Each turn, players all draw one Hay, Water and Equus (Love) card. They then draw an additional card of any type matching a territory they control. Each of these card types has one of four actions on it (Breed, Attack, Gallop or "Turn into Glue"). After drawing, and without being allowed to speak to each other, players place up to three cards facedown in front of them and then reveal and action those cards one at a time. If teammates both reveal the same action, they get a bonus.

So, you must mind-meld with your partner, control the board, and collect up to 20 horseshoes to win the game.

—description from the publisher
categories: Animals, Bluffing, Card Game, Deduction, Humor, Print & Play, Territory Building
mechanics: Action Queue, Area Majority / Influence, Cooperative Game, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Wizards and Warzones: Trading Card Game
description:
The way the game works is each player has a deck of 40~60 cards, after shuffling you draw 6 cards from the deck, decide who goes first, etc. then each player starts with 30 Loyalty (its like your Life Points) and 10 resources (just as important as Loyalty). Each player will spend their resources to play creatures to attack their opponents with and defend their Base (their side of the field), and play powerful spells, weapons, and artifacts to power up their creatures! Be careful though, because you might trigger an opponents Event card! (It's like an instant or a trap card) and then you might get set back as a result! Plan carefully as you set up your Terrain cards (Their like lands and field cards) to bolster your creatures defenses (by giving them a safe place to hide) and be prepared when you play your Epics (similar to legendary artifacts) because though they may greatly aid your creatures, one slip up and it could be stolen from you, if that happens 3 times you lose the game! Oh and don't forget to pay attention to the placement of your creatures to (because it matters big time!) If your not careful you might leave your weakest creature on the Front Lines (where it can be attacked) when it should have stayed in your Base (where its more safe)

—description from the designer
categories: Abstract Strategy, Card Game, Fantasy, Wargame
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Pick-up and Deliver, Player Elimination, Variable Phase Order, Variable Player Powers

name: Box Quiz: Danmark
description:
One of the over 50 implementations of the Box Quiz series, this one with the theme 'Denmark'.

The game consists of a tin box with 50 questions and answers within a category, here about Denmark. It is a small and simple quiz game, where players simply answer the different questions.

name: Box Quiz: Grubleren
description:
One of the over 50 implementations of the Box Quiz series, this one with the theme 'Thinking'.

The game consists of a tin box with 50 questions and answers within a category, here about figuring out if certain sentences are right or wrong. It is a small and simple quiz game, where players simply answer the different questions.

name: Dug Outs and Trenches
description:
World War 1 Australian war game for 2 players from the National Game Company. The object of the game is for each player to strategically place 9 howitzers playing pieces in a position along a World war 1 trench line to capture their opponents howitzers.

When 3 howitzers are in aligned along the trench line the player calls out "Trio" and may remove any opponents howitzers. Failure to make this call forfeits the opportunity of a capture.

Players take turns in moving howitzers around the trenches to align their howitzer guns. If a player places a howitzer in a position where trenches meet thus completing a trio in two directions he may call "Terror" and either captures an opponents piece or replace a gun previously lost.

The game is over when a player does not have enough howitzers to form a trio and he has lost the battle.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Wargame, World War I

name: Box Quiz: 3 på Tid
description:
One of the over 50 implementations of the Box Quiz series, this one with the theme '3 in Time'.

The game consists of a tin box with 50 questions and answers within a category, here you get 3 simple questions that you have to answer quickly. It is a small and simple quiz game, where players simply answer the different questions.

name: Ben 10 Alien Force Challenge
description:
This game comes in a plastic suitcase, with a quite large board, 120 cards and two dice.

It's a kind of roll and move game, but special rules make the playing time longer and the gameplay more exciting. On certain places of the board there are specific 'challenges' or random 'challenges' according to the card the player takes. Challanges can be solved by a 12-sided die, and even 3 helper cards can add a bonus. For every solved challenge the player gets so called 'Omnitrix' cards.

Players have to use a 6-sided die for moving, but only the numbers 1, 2 and 3 can be found on it, and if they roll 3 then they may move backward, too.

The game ends for a player when he/or she reaches the center of the board, however the winner is the player with the most Omnitrix card. So it's a good strategy to move back every time if possible.

The story according to the prologue from the rulebook is that Ben Tennyson and his team (Kevin Levin and Gwen Tennyson) look for a 4th person to the team. The players compete for this opportunity.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Ghost Rockers: Lost Instruments
description:
Look for the lost instruments in the school of Ghost Rockers. Return them and race to the secret rehearsal room.

Everybody is looking for the instruments at the same time. Players can hamper other players by closing doors or snatching instruments away from each other.

But it gets really exciting when the enchanted Ghost Rockers' instruments appear. When the last enchanted instrument appears the game comes to an end and players should race to the rehearsal room.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Music

name: Juego de las elecciones
description:
Players try to win elections by playing cards. At the beginning, two dice are thrown and multiplied by ten thousand to know how many votes must be obtained to win.

Players then place positive cards in front, and opponents can place negative cards in front of others. Each of the five different positive cards allows you to start a stack.

A player can not have more than one stack of the same quality.

If you are blocked in a stack, you can unlock it with a positive card of the same type.

According to the stacks that you have unlocked you can place votes in front of you. These do not count how one of the stacks allowed.

There are televised debates that begin with a card, and that are resolved by rolling a dice each opponent and adding their unblocked stacks.

Win the first to get the necessary votes.

—user summary

name: Continuation Trivia: Set One
description: Trivia game released by British retailer W H Smith to use in conjunction with the original Trivia Pursuit. It's basically 3,000 additional questions on 500 cards, in a box!

name: Caduta Libera Junior
description:
Answer correctly to all the question to increase your possibility to win as much money as possible. In this game, everytime someone is wrong, another one wins.

Every match is composed of 10 rounds: at the end of the round, an amount of money is assigned to the player who makes is opponent to fall down. The player with most money at the end of the game, will win.

This version contains simplified questions for junior players.

name: Il Gioco di Cotto e Mangiato
description:
You are part of the staff who must prepare the recipes for the next episodes of Cotto and Mangiato. When you notice that some essential ingredients for making dishes are not available, you go to the nearby market to try to recover the missing ingredients as quickly as possible, taking them from the available stock of ingredients, as an action.

The game plan represents a market, with 11 stalls, each of which has several products. Each stall is identified by a symbol that determines the type of products on sale.

The player who will be able to complete the higher number of recipes will win the game.

name: Mini-Memo
description:
Where have both hedgehogs holed up? Where have the two fish disappeared to, and where is the pair of bears? To find out, concentration and a good memory are required in Mini-Memo. The player who can best remember the same pictures and therefore collect the most card pairs wins. A fun and colorful memory game.

How to play:

The player whose turn it is turns over two memory cards, one after the other.

Do they show the same picture?
Excellent! Keep these two memory cards. You may then turn over two more cards.

Do they show different pictures?
What a pity! After everyone has seen the memory cards, turn them back over again.

The game ends when all the cards have been turned over and therefore all the pairs have been found. Stack your own memory cards. Whoever can build the highest card tower wins the game.

name: Control: The Fates of the World
description:
You are a Prime Mage. Unfortunately, so is your opponent. Your opposing wills for the fate of the world will have to be resolved as they always are, where kings are pawns, on the board populated by the Souls of millions, in this broad land under the sun.

Control was designed with the idea that the best part about playing card games is playing cards. You and your opponent each bring a 14 card deck to the table. There are a total of eight possible colors of cards to make your deck from. On your turns, you can play as many cards of two colors as you want, and once per game you may switch you hand and your deck. This means that you could play all of your cards on your first turn (if you made a two color deck).

However, you would lose the game. To win, you must cause your opponent to have zero cards in her deck. This means that you have to strike the right balance in how many cards you play and when you play them.

The game has full color cards for print and play, printer friendly cards, and a Tabletop Simulator module.

name: Cultists of Cthulhu: Art Gallery
description: There is a gallery showing at Miskatonic University, and the campus is covered in pieces of art. Some are beautiful, while some are horrifying, but all will leave an impression. This contains a new type of card, the Work of Art, which are spread around the map. Examining them can grant you bonuses, or scare you out of your wits, depending on how discerning your taste is. Contains 25 Art cards, 1 Cultist Card (Pickman's Model). A subset of art cards are placed face down in rooms on the map, and when examined, are revealed, and have an effect on everyone in that tile, and remain for the duration of the game.

name: Cultists of Cthulhu: Music Recital
description: Old folks may disapprove of it, but college kids know that there' s just something magical about that Jazz. Includes a deck of 13 Music Cards and rules for how to use them. Music is an optional rule: play the 15 minute soundtrack, which functions as a timer. Every 15 minutes a loud, easily noticable bell will prompt you to draw a new card from the Music Deck. Music cards can be good or bad for the Academics, and are resolved by whoever the current player is.

name: Cultists of Cthulhu: Tomes and Spells
description: There wouldn't be much point in having this amazing library if nobody ever read anything in it, right? Includes Forbidden Book Cards which are hazardous to read at best, and at worst, outright maddening to try to understand. If you do understand them, though, you just might get access to the new selection of Spell Cards. The Forbidden Books are the Book of Eibon, De Vermis Mysteriis, Unaussprechlichen Kulten, and Cultes des Ghoules, as well as an alternate version of the Necronomicon. Also contains 13 Spell Cards and rules governing how to use them.

name: Cultists of Cthulhu: The Dunwich Horror
description: In this all new scenario, the Cultist is either Wilbur Whateley or an agent of his, sent to retrieve the Necronomicon from the library and use it to unleash the terrifying, invisible Dunwich Horror upon the world.

name: Cultists of Cthulhu: The Great Race of Yith
description: This scenario is unique in that it is not played on its own, but can be added to any other scenario, creating two Cultists working at cross purposes. The Yith want to abduct your minds to learn from you, and the Academics and the other Cultist want none of that!

name: Cultists of Cthulhu: Character Pack
description: Four extra characters: the hobo who hangs out on campus, the groundskeeper, a townie who tends bar at the local watering hole, and one secret character!

name: Assassin Bug (fan expansion for Hive)
description:
The Assassin bug moves one space around the Hive. Or, instead it can use its special ability to remove an adjacent enemy piece that's not in a stack. To do this it moves on top of the enemy piece permanently removing both the enemy piece and the Assassin bug from the game. The Assassin
bug cannot remove a piece your opponent has just moved or flipped.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Expansion for Base-game, Fan Expansion

name: Butterfly (fan expansion for Hive)
description: The Butterfly moves two spaces on top of the Hive but cannot move down off the Hive.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Expansion for Base-game, Fan Expansion

name: PolitiCraft
description: PolitiCraft is a narrative-based "action civics" card game that guides players through varying levels of civic engagement. Through game play, students are guided by the deck to craft narratives based upon civic issues of their choosing. Doing so informs participants of multiple pathways available to them to achieve real change in their communities.
mechanics: Acting, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Role Playing, Simulation, Team-Based Game, Voting

name: Exodus Trading Card Game: Crystal Forge
description:
Crystal Forge is the 3rd set in the Exodus TCG.

Set Description:

Guild Wars on the Horizon:
Ever since the galaxy-sized nebula creatures collided in the skies over Eeventide, there's been a surplus of stardust & other magical compounds that rained down during the aftermath. This excess supply has led to Drifters far and wide forging new creatures. The emergence of 2 new Guilds, Treeforge & Shardveil, brings all to the brink of war.

Shardveil, their ice not limited to any part of the color spectrum, seeks to bring a halt to the chaos by permanently freezing the world. Treeforge and their vast forests of living trees & mushrooms fight to uproot the spreading ice. Which Guild do you choose?

A Competitive Expansion (Set 3) Crystal Forge:
With new Rarity mechanics, new creature types, & new effects like Reveal and Freeze, the Crystal Forge expansion set introduces all-new cards with new themes & new artwork all jam-packed into 2 new decks that are ready-to-play & fully customizable! None of these cards can be found in other sets!

Details:

This set consists of 2 Competitive Decks. The Treeforge Competitive Deck revolves around Treefolk & Mushfolk and the Shardveil Competitive Deck features ice creatures of all colors, shapes and sizes called Shardfolk. These decks are geared for advanced players who are already familiar with the basics of the game and heavily feature type and rarity mechanics. The decks can be played standalone or customized, and many players purchase 2 of each deck to get a playset (x2 copies) of each card since the set contains 100% new cards. This set contains extremely powerful Ability creatures that combo well with their respective types, and both decks feature a completely blinged-out 20-card foil energy deck with new artwork and a new foil treatment.
